During the summer months, we'll set off early to avoid the midday heat. Known as the 'Doorway to the Desert', Ouarzazate is in the south of the High Atlas, sandwiched between the high mountains and the expanses of the Sahara. It's home to the Atlas Film Studios, one of the largest studios in the world, where scenes from films including The Mummy, Gladiator, Babel, Kingdom of Heaven and Lawrence of Arabia were shot. We'll pay a visit to the studios and tour the famous film sets after which we head to a hotel in Ouarzazate for lunch followed by a dip in the pool; continuing on through the Draa Valley after lunch. Our drive will take us across a landscape lined with palm groves, kasbahs and traditional ksours (villages), as we make our way to Tamnougalt, once the capital of this remote desert region. The village's name translates to 'meeting point' and even today it hosts an annual festival in October, when people from the surrounding villages gather to celebrate the traditions of the region's old ruling quaids (masters). Tonight, we'll stay in a kasbah-style hotel in the middle of the Draa Valley, which has a swimming pool and access to valley walks.

dayInfo.title: Drive via Zagora to Ouled Driss oasis to camp in the desert
dayInfo.description: : Turning south today, we'll follow the course of the Draa River, spending the morning driving through the changing scenery towards the oasis of Zagora, 'The Gate of the Desert'. Once a major outpost along the caravan route, it apparently takes 52 days by camel from here to Timbuktu. We break for lunch in Zagora before continuing onto Ouled Driss, on the fringes of the sand dunes, giving us a taste of the grand expanse of the Sahara. From here, we'll hop off our bus and onto camels, creating our own caravan as we head into the Oued Ben Akki dunes. We'll stop to enjoy the quiet desolation of desert life before we reach our overnight camp in time for a late afternoon bread-making session. Finally, we'll tuck into a hearty Berber dinner under the star-strewn sky of the Sahara. Our desert camp has a combination of two-person and three-to-four-person family tents with a central communal tent for meals.

dayInfo.title: Visit Tamegroute and drive to Ouarzazate
dayInfo.description: : Retracing our steps, this morning we'll head back north on camelback. Meeting our bus on the road, we'll journey on to Tamegroute, where we'll stop to visit the 17th-century zaouia (a multi-functional space of worship and learning). This was once the base of the Naciri Brotherhood, the holy leaders of Tamegroute and arbitrators of desert disputes. We'll also pay a visit to the local potters' cooperative before continuing back to Ouarzazate later in the afternoon.

dayInfo.title: Drive to Marrakech for city tour
dayInfo.description: : Today we drive back to the Red City and dive straight into the heady delights of Marrakech with a guided tour. We'll pass by the rose-coloured Koutoubia (booksellers) Mosque on the way to Bahia Palace, an open-air museum that's famous for its decorated stucco walls and marble floors. We'll fuel up on fresh pastries from a traditional bakery before continuing to the medina on foot. There, we'll be guided through the labyrinth of spice-scented souks, passing by craftsmen selling rugs, leather goods and crockery before dropping by a spice shop to sample ripe dates and almonds. Finally, we'll navigate our way out into the energetic Jemaa el-Fna Square.

dayInfo.title: Trip ends in Marrakech
dayInfo.description: : Our tour of Morocco ends at our hotel in Marrakech. There are no activities planned today, so you're free to depart at any time. If your flight is departing later in the day, luggage storage facilities are available at our hotel. If you'd like an airport transfer, you'll need to depart from Marrakesh Menara Airport (RAK).

placesVisited: Marrakech, Ouarzazate, gateway to the Sahara, Camel trek at Erg Chebbi, Berber camp on the edge of the desert, Todra Gorge, Ait Benhaddou, Optional activities include hot air ballooning in Marrakech, rock climbing in Todra Gorge, and quad biking or a film studio visit at Ouarzazate
generalInfo:
If you want a family adventure with a wild side, a desert, and some culture too, try this tour between Marrakech and the Sahara. You’ll also travel via Todra Gorge and the Atlas Mountains: that’s a heap of all-star sights for all the family.

Teens won’t feel like they’ve outgrown a family holiday when they’re here. This tour has been designed based on our partner’s years of expertise at crafting itineraries and finding the activities that work best for families with older children. There’s action and adventure, plus shopping, film sets, and culture – so kids with diverse interests will all be satisfied.

Marrakech provides wonderful chances to immerse yourselves in the colourful medina, and enjoy fantastic food. Then, as you explore the country, you’ll find the desert landscape is a fantastic playground for thrill-seekers. Try quad biking in Ouarzazate, the gateway to the Sahara Desert, or rock climbing in the Todra Gorge.

For families, experiencing somewhere new together is a great bonding activity – especially when you’re all a little out of your comfort zone. Laugh together as you all try camel trekking for the first time, and share stories round a Berber campfire.

You’ll be travelling with a company who are doing their bit to support school children in the Atlas Mountains, by paying for boarding school fees and transportation fees for children living in a small village in the region.

dayInfo.description: Welcome to Morocco! Following your transfer from the airport to our joining hotel, you can relax by the hotel pool before the pre-departure meeting at 18.00 hrs where you will meet your guide and fellow travellers. Overnight Marrakech (Dinner included).

Following breakfast, we travel to Ouarzazate. After lunch, there is a chance for either an optional tour of the Film studios, famous for films such as Gladiators, The Last Temptation of Christ and the Living Daylights, Quad biking or just explore Ouarzazate. Depending on time, it may be possible to do more than one of these options. Overnight Ouarzazate (Breakfast & Dinner included).

Excitement is in the air as we head towards the mighty Saharan Dunes. En-route we stop off for lunch and in the summer, we may even have time for a relaxing swim. It is then time to head towards the great desert dunes of Erg Chebbi in Merzouga where we transfer to our camels and trek into the vast Sahara Desert in time for sunset. We then return to our authentic Berber Camp on the edge of the desert to spend the night enjoying local food, music, and an amazing night out under the Saharan stars. Overnight Berber camp (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included).

After a wonderful breakfast in the dunes, we leave the desert and stop along the way to visit ancient irrigation wells where you can see how they were created from an intricate network of underground canals running from the Atlas to the Sahara, more than 300km and dating back to the 14th Century. We move on to stunning Todra Gorge and have lunch at our hotel, set amongst the Palmeries and hemmed in by 300M high cliffs. We have time to explore the gorge after lunch or go for some optional rock climbing. We will visit Tizgui, one of the old villages of Todra and visit a local carpet cooperative where we learn how to make Moroccan tea and Berber rugs. Overnight Todra Gorge (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included).

We have a leisurely depart from Todra this morning as we head off to Ait Benhaddou. On the road also known as the road of a thousand Kasbah’s, we will make a stop at Kasbah Amridil. This is one of the best Kasbah examples in Morocco and once featured on the Moroccan 50 Dirham bank note. We arrive at Ait Benhaddou, a UNESCO World Heritage site for lunch. We will take a guided tour of Ait Benhaddou this afternoon, a traditional pre-Saharan habitat of earthen walled dwellings fortified by surrounding walls and guarded by 4 corner towers. This evening, we will enjoy dinner and soak up the atmosphere of this inspiring place. Overnight Ait Benhaddou (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included).

We will depart this morning traversing the mighty and impressive High Atlas Mountains en-route to Marrakech. You can enjoy a free afternoon by the pool in Marrakech, experience the hustle and bustle of the medina, eat in Djemaa el Fna square, shop, visit Jardin Majorelle or if you prefer a quieter time, relax with a hammam spa at the hotel. An optional cooking class can take place this evening on a family home visit. This is a mutual exchange where we learn how to cook a tagine and about family life in Morocco and our cooking class cost helps the family out too. Overnight Marrakech (Breakfast included).

There is time today to take an optional hot air balloon ride before breakfast followed by a morning guided city tour (optional) of Marrakech which takes approximately 3 hours and includes Bahia Palace, The Medina, pharmacy visit and a walk around the Koutoubia Mosque. Or explore the sights for yourself and soak up the incredible atmosphere on your last free afternoon. This evening, we have our final group meal in the Djemaa El Fna, the legendary main square full of acrobats, snake charmers, juice sellers and various open-air restaurants. Overnight Marrakech (Breakfast & Dinner).
Your adventure tour ends after breakfast, and it is time to say goodbye. (Breakfast included).

placesVisited: Guided tour of Marrakech, Aroumd village, Zaouit Ifergane, bread cooking demonstration, Essaouira, camel ride across the desert
generalInfo:
Close to the UK, just a 2hr flight, but a world away in terms of adventure, Morocco offers families a holiday that’s out of the ordinary and packed full of excitingly authentic experiences to keep kids and adults completely and utterly enthralled.

Morocco’s cities provide a portal into the past with spice markets, ancient city walls, street performers, snake charmers and musicians making guided tours of Marrakech all the more memorable.

A short journey south reveals rural settings and Berber villages amongst the Mizane Valley, in the High Atlas, where your family will discover the delights of bread making and traditional handicrafts before enjoying down time around the pool at accommodation in Zaouit Ifergane.

Camel rides, beaches and swashbuckling tales of pirates past await in Essaouira where colourful fishing boats conjure a charming setting for seafood suppers on the harbour prior to undertaking the 3hr journey east for one last magical night in Marrakech.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech.
dayInfo.description: Salaam Aleikum! Welcome to Morocco. Your adventure begins in Marrakech – a feast for the senses and a world of spice markets, Amazigh music, carpets, acrobats and perfumed gardens. You can arrive at any time today before your welcome meeting at 5 pm. If you have an arrival transfer booked, please look for a representative when you arrive at the airport. Your hotel is located just outside the city walls around the old medina, about a 30-minute walk to the main square, Djemaa el-Fna – the largest public square in the world. It's also near a lot of local shops and restaurants, so there’s plenty to do if you arrive early. After your meeting, why not head out to dinner with the group and get to know each other.

dayInfo.title: Aroumd.
dayInfo.description: Today's adventure begins with a drive over the High Atlas Mountains to the village of Imlil – the largest village in the Mizane Valley. You’ll store your main luggage here, before continuing on foot to the traditional mountain village of Aroumd with your daypack. If you don't feel comfortable with the walk, your leader can arrange a mule for you to ride instead (the kids will surely love the mule ride!). Perched on a rocky outcrop, the remote village of Aroumd offers views across the High Atlas Mountains and a unique opportunity to experience traditional Amazigh culture. Spend tonight in a family-run mountain home (gite) in Aroumd. Surrounded by the smell of woodstoves and bread, you’ll meet the host family and enjoy some traditional food together.

dayInfo.title: Taroudant .
dayInfo.description: This morning, you'll have a bread cooking demonstration for breakfast and maybe an early morning walk around the village of Imlil. Transfer to Taroudant, passing through some Amazigh villages and across the High Altas Mountains via the Tizi n Tast, which gives you a great view of the largest plain of Sous. Arriving at your accommodation in the late afternoon, maybe take the kids for a swim in the pool and have a relaxing evening.

dayInfo.title: Taroudant .
dayInfo.description: Today after breakfast, take a fun donkey ride through the picturesque oasis of Tiout. This is not your average city tour – by exploring the gorgeous oasis on the back of a donkey, you’ll be immersed in the local way of life and travel as the locals do. The oasis is full of palm trees and streams of running water, giving an exotic atmosphere full of sights, smells and sounds. By hiring these donkeys and their guides, you'll be directly supporting the local community and ensuring that the animals are well taken care of, providing ample food and shelter. After your tour, join a local woman in her home for a traditional homemade lunch. Not only will this experience leave you feeling full and happy, but it also supports the local community by providing income for the women in the village who prepare the meal with love and care.

dayInfo.title: Sidi Kaouki - Essaouira.
dayInfo.description: After breakfast this morning, you'll travel up the coast to Sidi Kaouki. Mount a camel and take in the view as the waves crash along the shoreline, taking in the awesome scenery as you plod along. This may well be one of the highlights of your trip! Enjoy a picnic lunch on the beach, then board the bus again and head to Essaouira. This delightful artists' town is a former Portuguese trading colony and was once home to sizeable British and Jewish populations. The town faces a group of rocky islands called the Mogador and is surrounded by an expanse of sandy beaches and dunes. It's still a busy fishing port, and its pretty harbour is filled with tiny colourful fishing boats which go out early every morning.

dayInfo.title: Essaouira .
dayInfo.description: Today is free for you to explore Essaouira. Everything in the small centre is within walking distance, and the beach is perfect for a long walk. Why not wander the harbour and its adjacent fish markets where you can witness the daily auction – a freshly-cooked plate of the day's catch is highly recommended. Maybe take the kids to browse some of the many shops and art galleries where unique local pieces are on display. The town is becoming renowned for its burled Thuya wood, delicately formed, inlaid and polished with oils. The scent from the oils fills the air and makes walking through the streets a delight for the senses!

dayInfo.title: Marrakech.
dayInfo.description: Leaving Essaouira behind, journey inland to Marrakech. Enjoy an afternoon walking tour of the city centre, taking in the main sights on your way to the sprawling Djemaa el-Fna main square and souq. As is usual in a souq, individual trades and crafts are concentrated in one street or area, so the shoemakers are all next to each other, as are the jewellers, potters and weavers. This is the best place in Morocco to sharpen your bargaining skills, and you are almost certain to be tempted by some of the extraordinary variety of merchandise on display – perhaps a pair of traditional Moroccan slippers or some spices. The market almost has the atmosphere of a medieval fair. Fortune tellers and jugglers are among those who vie to entertain you. In the evening, wonderful smells waft by as food stalls cook up their local delicacies.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech.
dayInfo.description: Your trip comes to an end this morning. There are no activities planned for the final day and you are free to depart the accommodation at any time. If you’d like to extend your stay in Marrakech, just get in touch with your booking agent ahead of time.

tourName: Morocco family tour, camels, kasbahs & beach
placesVisited: Marrakech, High Atlas Mountains, Ait Benhaddou, N'Kob, Draa Valley, Camel trek into the Sahara Desert, Spend the night at a Berber desert camp, Todra Gorge, Visit a Berber handicrafts cooperative, Roses Valley, Essaouira
generalInfo:
This 12-day small group tour of Morocco, a round-trip from Marrakech, is ideal for families with a little more time to spend as it finishes with a few days to relax by the coast in the charming fishing town of Essaouira. Enjoy a relaxed and fun tour of must-see destinations and must-do activities on a small group tour that has been created with families in mind.

This is a perfect Morocco holiday if you’re travelling with kids, because the itinerary has been slowed down to allow plenty of time to unwind. Your kids will also have other children to hang around with. And, of course, Morocco is a lovely country to travel as a family, with a very welcoming culture, great food, and lots of attractions that will capture young imaginations.

For instance, picture yourselves trekking over the sand dunes of the Sahara Desert at sunset, the kids getting to know the names and personalities of their camels. Or bedding down under the stars at an authentic Bedouin camp on the edge of the desert, after a feast around the campfire. Or exploring the ancient kasbahs of Ait Benhaddou, and entertaining the kids with stories about the many Hollywood films shot there.

In Marrakech, you can take an evening tour of the central square where the kids’ eyes will be widened by the sight of dancers and acrobats, musicians, fortune tellers and henna artists all plying their trade. Meanwhile the aromas from the food stalls will prove intoxicating, and irresistible.

You’ll walk through the Todra Gorge, Morocco’s answer to the Grand Canyon; explore a desert oasis, and a Berber handicrafts cooperative, and enjoy stunning views in the High Atlas Mountains. And all this before you reach the coast at Essaouira. Here, in this picturesque fishing town you can wander with your cameras, relax with your toes in the sand, or even try some surfing lessons.

Like all the best family holidays, you’ll come home from this trip happy, relaxed, and well-fed. It’s likely that you’ll also have developed a fascination for Moroccan culture, as the tour leaders are brilliant at showing you what makes their home so special.

dayInfo.description: Welcome to Morocco! Following your transfer from the airport to our joining hotel, you can relax by the hotel pool before the pre-departure meeting at 18:00 hrs where you will meet your guide and fellow travellers. Overnight Marrakech (Dinner included).

Straight after breakfast, we will drive crossing the High Atlas Mountains. On arrival in Ait Benhaddou, we will have lunch and relax by the pool before we go for a guided tour of the village to learn about its rich history. Ait Benhaddou is one of the oldest villages in the south of Morocco and used as a backdrop for many international movies like Gladiator. Probably most famous of all are its old and splendid Kasbahs. Overnight in Ait Benhaddou (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included).

Our journey today takes us to the Berber Oasis of N’kob. We will be driving through the Anti Atlas ranges to cross The Draa Valley which is one of the most famous places in Morocco for dates; we can stop and try some fresh ones if you like (season dependent). N’Kob is one of Morocco’s best kept secrets, nestled amongst the exotic Palmeries and sat at the foot of the Jebel Saghro mountains. We will have time today to explore some of N’kob’s 45 mudbrick ksour’s (fortified village). We will learn about Ait Atta Nomad’s and their way of life. There will be some time to walk through the Palmerie and soak up the stunning views around followed by having tea in a local family’s home or head back to the hotel to relax for the afternoon. Overnight in N’Kob. (Breakfast & Dinner included).

Excitement is in the air as we head towards the mighty Saharan Dunes. En-route we stop off for lunch and in the summer, we may even have time for a relaxing swim. It is then time to head towards the great desert dunes of Erg Chebbi in Merzouga where we transfer to our camels and trek into the vast Sahara Desert in time for sunset. We then return to our authentic Berber Camp on the edge of the desert to spend the night enjoying local food, music, and an amazing night out under the Saharan stars. Overnight Berber camp (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included).

Leaving the desert, we move on to Todra Gorge. This 1000ft gorge is hemmed in on all sides by vertical limestone cliffs and is also called Morocco’s Grand Canyon. From its plunging depths to dizzying heights. The charm of Todra lies in its changing colours as the sun slowly moves from east to west. We will have time this afternoon to explore the Gorge with a visit to a traditional Berber cooperative for Berber carpets owned by local people. We will learn how the Berbers make their carpets and you will have chance to try your bargaining skills if you are interested in buying one. For those that fancy a cooking lesson, we will have an option to do this today to prepare and cook your own Moroccan lunch. Overnight Todra Gorge (Breakfast & Dinner included).

After breakfast, we head off through the road of The Roses Valley, famous in Morocco for roses. We will have a stop if you want to see a variety of different rose products (season dependent). Our journey continues to Ouarzazate (the Hollywood of North Africa), which African traders once used on their journeys up to Europe. We can make an optional visit to the famous film studios which have been used for films such as The Kingdom of Heaven, Alexander the Great, The Last Temptation of Christ and The Living Daylights. Overnight in Ouarzazate (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included).

Today, we will drive back to Marrakech crossing the High Atlas Mountains enjoying its’ magnificent views en-route. After checking in at our Marrakech hotel, you will have a free afternoon. This evening is a chance to enjoy the exotic ambience of dinner in the famous square of Djemaa El Fna. Overnight in Marrakech (Breakfast & Dinner included).

This morning, why not book our optional guided city tour of Marrakech which includes the Koutoubia Mosque, Bahia palace, and the Jewish quarter? In the afternoon, there will be time to explore the city independently. Within the rose-coloured walls of the medina, you find a reality that is not that far removed from a film set and ancient history; winding streets that open onto lush gardens and dark alleyways that lead to bustling souks. The focal point is the central square, the Djemaa el Fna, an extraordinary gathering point and marketplace. Full of colour, spicy aromas, and traders, it is best seen in the evening when overflowing with food stalls, dancers, acrobats, fortune tellers, musicians, and henna artists. Overnight Marrakech (Breakfast included).

We will be leaving those on the 9-day tour behind this morning as we take a leisurely drive to Essaouira; a colourful fishing town situated within 15th century Portuguese fortifications, where great beaches and surf beckon. Relax on the beach or alternatively explore the UNESCO-listed medina with its various souks and woodcarving workshops. Any city gate leads to the medina, so you are unlikely to get lost. The beach is in front of the Medina and there are plenty of cafés with terraces, both ideal for relaxing for a few hours. Blue doors and window frames abound as do the artists shops – buy a carpet or Thuya wood carving or sit on the beach sipping a mint tea as the sun sets, an antidote to the hustle & bustle of the Imperial cities. There is the opportunity to do some optional activities, such as quad biking, surfing, horse trekking and wind surfing or you can just simply sit on the beach and relax! Overnight Essaouira (Breakfast included).
Enjoy the beach and our optional activities again! Overnight Essaouira (Breakfast included).

We use the Supratours public bus to head back to Marrakech mid-morning, before heading to the famous Djemma el Fna square for an optional group meal in the evening. Overnight Marrakech (Breakfast included).
The tour ends after breakfast. (Breakfast included).

generalInfo:
Discover Morocco: A 15-Day Journey of Culture, History, and Natural Beauty

Embark on an extraordinary 15-day expedition through Morocco’s most captivating landscapes. This meticulously designed tour guides you from the cosmopolitan energy of Casablanca to the vibrant heart of Marrakech, revealing the nation’s remarkable diversity—from towering mountains to the vast, golden expanse of the Sahara Desert.

Throughout your journey, you will experience Morocco’s iconic landmarks, including the Hassan II Mosque in Casablanca, Africa’s largest and most architecturally impressive mosque. Stroll through historic towns and villages such as the UNESCO World Heritage site of Kasbah Aït Ben Haddou, celebrated for its striking architecture and timeless charm.

The adventure culminates in a magical sunrise camel ride across the Sahara dunes, followed by an overnight stay under the stars at a traditional Berber camp—offering an authentic connection to Morocco’s rich heritage and serene landscapes.

Itinerary Highlights

Imperial Cities: Explore Casablanca, Rabat, Meknes, Fes, and Marrakech.

Desert Experience: Journey through Merzouga, traverse sweeping dunes, enjoy a camel ride, and overnight in a desert camp.

Atlas Mountains: Cross the High Atlas via Tizi n’Tichka Pass, visiting Berber villages along the way.

Southern Morocco: Discover historic kasbahs along ancient caravan routes, including Ouarzazate, Aït Ben Haddou, and the Dades & Todra Gorges.

Coastal and Northern Gems: Visit the coastal city of Essaouira and the iconic blue city of Chefchaouen.

Natural Wonders: Experience breathtaking gorges, valleys, oases, and scenic vistas with opportunities to witness stunning sunrises and sunsets.

Authentic Experiences & Cultural Immersion

Extended stays in smaller towns and villages to gain insight into rural life.

Homestays in locally run guesthouses with welcoming hosts.

Workshops and artisan visits off the typical tourist path.

Participation in traditional activities such as bread-making, mill visits, and local market experiences.

Engagement with local guides intimately familiar with the communities visited, ensuring respectful and culturally sensitive exploration.

dayInfo.description: You will be welcomed by your driver in the airport of Mohamed 5 in Casablanca and taken to your hotel, where you'll spend your first night. We ca also pick you up from another hotel, if you are already in Casablanca.TD>

After breakfast at the hotel, your real journey will begin by a visit to one of the most beautiful places in Casablanca, The Hassan II mosque - the largest of its kind in Africa. Afterwards, you'll be driven to Morocco’s capital city of Rabat - an imperial city where you’ll visit Mechouar, the tombs of Mohamed V and Hassan II, and the Kasbah of Oudayas. Overnight in your accommodation in Rabat.

After breakfast you'll be driven to Tangier through the quiet beach town of Asilah, where you'll stop for a wander, before continuing to Tangier to visit Cap spartel and the city itself. Overnight in Hotel in Tangier.

After breakfast you'll visit more of Tangier and Hercules' Cave before you set off for Chefchaouen, an outstanding town in a strategic location with white-blue houses. The town lies in a green oasis crossed by a river. Once you get to Chefchaouen you will check in to your hotel then have free time to visit the blue city.

After breakfast, you'll head to Meknes through the Rif mountains. Visit the Roman ruins of Volubilis and continue to Meknes where you'll visit the old Medina of this imperial city surrounded by ramparts, and visit Moulay Ismail mausoleum, the green gate of Bab Mansour, and Lahdim Square.Then continue to Visit the Medina of Meknes surrounded by its ramparts. Then continue to your riad in Fes.

You will explore Fes, starting with the old Medina where you will discover its narrow streets and the magic derived from its many historical monuments, including Al-Attarine Madrasa, Ennajarine Fountain, Al-Qarawiyyine university ( the oldest university in the world founded in 859), Bou Inania Madrasa and the Mausoleum of Moulay Idriss.Your exploration of the old Medina comes to an end after breakfast in a local eatery. Before returning to your accommodation for a rest, you'll stop by ‘Fes Al-jdid’, the new city. You'll lunch in a local restaurant and experience the panoramic view of the whole Medina of Fes before a short visit in the new city.

Setting out from Fes, you will cross the Middle Atlas mountains towards Ifran, enjoying the spectacle of Berber villages and Cedar forests along the way. Pass through Ifran, ‘little Switzerland’ as some like to call it in reference to its alpine beauty, and Azrou. The town of Midelt is where you will stay the night in a hotel.

Start your trip from Midelt and cross the valley of Ziz to see the wonderful expansive view of palmtrees. When you reach Erfoud, you will stop by fossil fossils, before driving towards the desert town of Merzouga. Arriving before sunset, you'll have the chance too have a walk in the desert and climb a sand dune to watch the sunset.

The area of Merzouga is full of places to visit: The first spot is Khamlia, the hometown of the dark-skinned ethnic group who will welcome you with a cup of tea while enjoying their traditional music. Next, the desert Lake where you will see several species of birds. Drive over the plains towards Rissani and Tafilalt, from where the Alaouite dynasty descend, and where you'll observe their fortified villages and souks. Then you'll head back to your hotel in the afternoon in order to go camel trekking over the sand dunes and watch the sunset before arriving at your desert camp in the heart of the dunes. Enjoy the remote quietness, the campfire and the sound of Berber music played by the locals.

In the morning, wake as earlier as you can so as not to miss the stunning sunrise, before breakfast in the camp. On your way to Todra Gorges, pass through Rissani and Tafilalt. Todra Gorges is a nice place with water springing from the rocky mountains and running down the green valley. You will also see the beautiful town of Boumalne Dades and the ‘Rose Valley’ known throughout Morocco as the capital of roses for its wide cultivation of roses, as well as apples, figs, corn…etc. En route the Kasbahs line our route, known as ‘the Road of a thousand Kasbahs’. Overnight at a riad in Ait Ben Hadou in front of the Kasabah.

After breakfast in the hotel you will have 2 hours with your local guide the explore Ait Ben Haddou Kasbah, before passing Taznakht and Taliouine, on our way to Taroudant. On our way, you can sieze the opportunity to visit Saffron fields where you will meet local farm ers in their fields. We’ll arrive in Taroudant by the afternoon and have a tour around the Medina which is surrounded by walls, and wander along its streets. Overnight in your hotel.

Drive to one of Morocco’s most visited cities, Agadir. After lunch we will take the quiet coastal road leading to Essaouira. Delight in seeing the beautiful scenery and the spectacle of Argan tree climbing goats.

Begin the day by visiting the seaport and the Medina, also called ‘Skala’ where you will see old structures and cannons, and visit the museum of Sidi Mohammed Ben Abd Llah and walk through the market to behold a myriad of products, including hand-made local crafts. Enjoy a seafood lunch. Then you will head eastwards to Marrakesh.

In the morning get ready to discover Marrakesh, Morocco’s touristic capital. Visit many impressive places, including: Menara, the Palaces of Bahia and Badi, and the Saadian mausoleums. Enjoy a Moroccan traditional lunch at a restaurant before resuming your exploration. Visit the Koutoubia Mosque, built in the 12th century, and Djemaa El Fna, the place no one misses when visiting Marrakesh. The attractive square of Djemaa El Fna is well-known for its vitality at night when people crowd around comedians, storytellers, snake charmers…etc
Your tour has come to an end and you will be transferred to the Airport. The itinerary can modify as much as you like. For more information or more details please get in touch

tourName: Morocco guided discovery tour from Marrakech
generalInfo:
Our Morocco Discovery tour starting in Marrakech will take you on a cultural adventure through beautiful towns and cities making you wish you had stayed for longer!

From the bustling red city of Marrakech with its vibrant souks, driving through the scenic High Atlas Mountains, we venture to a UNESCO World Heritage site Ait Benhaddou before a stay in the Erg Chebbi dunes at an authentic Berber camp where we can ride a camel and sleep amongst a million stars under a Saharan sky.

Soak up the history of medieval Fes with its winding, mysterious alleyways, and incredible leather tanneries before reaching everyone’s favourite blue pearl Chefchaouen. This blue city is an unmissable hidden gem with stunning views of the Rif mountains.

Moving on to the capital of Rabat and its’ major landmarks before arriving at the fascinating city of Casablanca, one of the largest and most historical cities in Africa where you will see the Hassan II Mosque standing tall over the Atlantic Ocean.

We end this amazing tour back in Marrakech with memories of a lifetime. Finish your trip in this extraordinary marketplace taking in all the aromas, sights, and sounds.

Highlights:
Casablanca - Hassan II Mosque, the largest Mosque in Morocco
Rabat - Lively capital of Morocco & its Royal Palace
Chefchaouen - Morocco’s famous blue city
Fes - Ancient bustling city with dye-pits & tanneries
Sahara Desert - Authentic Berber Camp in the Erg Chebbi dunes with camel trek
Todra Gorge - Morocco’s “Grand Canyon”
Ait Benhaddou - UNESCO listed ancient Kasbah city.
Marrakech - Djemaa-el-Fna square, UNESCO-listed medina
Boumalne Dades – Charming landscapes and gorges
Rif Mountains - Beautiful Mountain vistas

dayInfo.description: We welcome you to majestic Morocco! Following your transfer from the airport to our joining hotel, you can relax by the hotel pool before the pre-departure meeting at 18.00 hrs where you will meet your fellow travellers. Overnight Marrakech (Dinner included).

This morning, we will start our journey by crossing the High Atlas Mountain of Morocco and arrive at the old village of Ait Benhaddou. This village was a major stop for the caravans in the old days thus it has become a UNESCO World heritage site and is used as a background for many international movies such as Gladiators, Prince of Persia and Game of Thrones. Not too far from this village is Ouarzazate, a city in the south of Morocco known as the Hollywood of North Africa due to the number of movies made at its film studios. On the way to Boumalne Dades, where we will stay for the night, we pass by the Roses Valley, a beautiful evergreen area famous for the damaskina roses. Locals hold a festival every year to celebrate the harvest. Overnight Boumalne Dades (Breakfast & Dinner included).

This morning, we will leave the Dades Valley. Along the drive, we take a short journey East to Todra Gorge where we will go for a nice walk through the palm groves of the oasis and a visit to its famous gorges. It is then time to head towards the great desert dunes of Erg Chebbi in Merzouga where we transfer to our camels and trek into the vast Sahara Desert in time for sunset. We then return to our authentic Berber Camp on the edge of the desert to spend the night enjoying local food, music, and an amazing night out under the sparkling Saharan stars. Overnight Saharan Berber Camp (Breakfast & Dinner included).

After breakfast we will drive through the city of Errachidia and the Ziz Valley that is incredibly famous for date palms. Afterwards, we will cross the High and the Middle Atlas Mountains that separate the Sahara Desert from the interior parts of the country. We will make a stop at the Cedar Forest on our way to see the barbary macaque apes. In addition, we will also stop in picturesque Ifran, an alpine style town that used to be a vacation place for the French during the French occupation of the country. We will then arrive in Fes, the oldest capital of Morocco where we will stay for the night. Overnight Fes (Breakfast included).

Today, is our guided tour of Fes. Fes is the oldest and largest medieval city in the world. Its medina, home to 400,000 inhabitants, with only donkeys and bikes as a means of transportation, is a heady mix of aromas, sights, and sounds. There are mosques and palaces to visit but be aware that only Muslims can enter mosques in Morocco. After exploring the dye-pits, tanneries, pharmacy, pottery, and restaurants, we return to our hotel to freshen up for tonight, where we have the chance of an optional traditional meal in the city with live Moroccan entertainment including traditional music, belly dancing and magicians. Overnight Fes (Breakfast included).

After breakfast, we will drive to ‘The Blue Pearl’ Chefchaouen for a guided tour this afternoon. High up in the Rif Mountains, historic Chefchaouen boasts a beautiful blue door and white-walled medina that was originally a Berber defence post. The main square is the heart of Chefchaouen, with the Kasbah (built back in the 18th century), central Mosque and cafes with authentic menus. The busy market is a mix of traditional Moroccan and tourist fare. There is a chance to have an optional cooking class today. Overnight Chefchaouen (Breakfast included).

With an early start this morning, we travel south to the official capital of Morocco, Rabat. On arrival, we will go on a guided tour of Rabat and its major landmarks such as the Hassan tower and the Mausoleum of the Alaouite King Mohamed V and his son Hassan II. Afterwards, we visit the Oudaya Kasbah, a fortified building that used to be a place to defend the city from the invasion of the European countries. After a tasty lunch in Rabat, we leave for Casablanca and head to our hotel. Overnight Casablanca (Breakfast included).

After breakfast before leaving Casablanca, we have the optional but recommended visit of Hassan II Mosque. We will then make our way back to the red city of Marrakech. Once checked in to the hotel, the afternoon will be free for you to relax by the pool or do more exploration at your own pace. Perhaps book our guided city tour, relax with a hammam spa and massage, or go to Majorelle gardens. Whilst here, you are unlikely to miss Marrakech’s main landmark, the rose coloured Koutoubia Mosque standing 77 metres high. The Mosque’s tower is sister to the Hassan Tower in Rabat and the Giralda Tower in Seville and located on the edge of the medina. No visit to Marrakech is complete without seeing the city’s UNESCO-listed medina & Djemaa-el-Fna square, (which means congregation); it is an extraordinary gathering and marketplace with snake charmers, musicians, henna artists and plenty of spice and souvenir stalls and where we will spend our final evening. Overnight Marrakech (Breakfast included).
Your adventure tour ends after breakfast. (Breakfast included).

generalInfo:
With ten days to explore you can dive deep into some of Morocco's hidden gems, explore highlight destinations whilst still having plenty of time to discover its more hidden corners - getting off the beaten track or just taking more time to soak the country in.
Touch down in Marrakesh, the tourism capital and quickly drive via the Tizi n’Test to Taroudant, the Souss Valley’s prettiest market town with its mud-walled medina and kasbah. Move south to Ida Ougnidif, a true small fortified village and continue to the tiny but viby Tafraoute, surrounded by beautiful Anti-Atlas scenery such as the Ameln Valley, with its lush palms and pink-hued houses, and also the famous Ait Mansour Gorges. From here, head west to Sidi Ifni, a jumble of wind-whipped art-deco relics surrounded by coastal walks. Arcing north, you come to Mirleft, with its pink-and blue arches, and then the friendly Agadir seaside resort and beautiful beaches. Continuing north via the spectacular ocean road, where hippies once gravitated, to Essaouira and its white-walled ramparts, bohemian beat and renovated riads that still make travellers linger. Set your wheels, direction east, to the icon of contemporary Morocco; Marrakesh. The city’s souk, street performers and imperial architecture form an intoxicating mix.

dayInfo.description: Airport Shuttle Welcome to land of peace and love! Transfer from Marrakech Airport to Your Hotel/Riad in Marrakech. Your Driver will pick you up from the airport and transfer you to your Hotel/Riad in Marrakech to relax, loosen up and prepare yourself to officially start your cultural tour.

This is your first day out of your busy life, today we head to Taroudant via the dam of lalla Takerkoust and Ouirgane with its stunning greenery, red-earth hills and pine forests. Passing through the rough road of Ijoukak where the Agoundis Valley joins the Nfis. Tinmel mosque is a worthwhile stop, the fascinating architectural isolated Monument above a lush reach of river valley with harsh mountains backing its buff-colored walls. Crossing the Tizi n’Test (2092m), the first modern route linking Marrakech with Souss plain. Arrive to Taroudant.

Today you will have a morning meeting with one of the most elegant purely Berber towns of Morocco with its majestic, tawny-brown and honey-gold circuit of 7km walls. While you stroll and linger around, note the distinctive, highly beautiful blue veils that many of older local ladies put on. Head south to Ida Ougnidif, a true small fortified village, the Kasbah of Tizourgane was essentially a fortified town, enclosing 25 houses, a mosque, a granary and a prison, and thick stone walls tower above the passages around the ancient structure. The Kasbah has been rehabilitated thanks to massive work undertaken by the owners, which continues today. The Kasbah has been renovated respecting the original construction techniques and materials. It has now become a guest house which allows you to enjoy this magical place that you’ll certainly love. In February, the argan and almond trees, in bloom, enhance the beauty of the place.

Today we are going to drive in about 65km heading south to the locked in a muscular, red-granite mountain embrace, and charming in a dusty windswept sort of way, Tafraoute is worth all the effort and time it takes to reach – « like the badlands of South Dakota », as Paul Bowles put it, «writ on a grand scale». The tiny but viby Tafrouate is a stoned-built villages with around five thousand hardy souls still one of the must-see relaxed destinations in the country of red and green flag. It worths a walk around to see curious rock formations such as Napolean’s Hat or the Peirres Pients, Painted blue and pink by a Belgium artist. Just 30km southeast of Tafraoute located the palm-filled gorges of Ait Mansour, where many people like to park up and stroll through the massive palmery, which is beautiful cool in the heat of the day. The palmery stretches a good 6km along the floor of the valley at the end of the day we loop back to Tafrouate.

Today we must say goodbye to the village that surrounded by a wind-eroded, jagged panorama of red-granite tors and craggy brown cliffs and rocks and onward to the most romantic Art Deco military town ever built on cliff top site. A real Santa Cruz del Mar Pequeno « Holy Cross of the Small Sea » that build in 1930. We will cross what is remained of the amazing view of Anti Atlas Mountains, if you’re lucky enough (and I am sure you are) we may come across a weekly market in one of the villages along the way. If so, we will surely take a deep look into it via a walk among the locals’s tents where they sell their goods. If so don’t hesitate to wander, it’s always fascinating to discover local life during such a weekly event. The road may not be the best, but it’s scenic and definitely worthy to be hit!

Set your compass for north through the Atlantic Ocean to experience a wonderful day driving by crossing a series of white good beaches of Atlantic Ocean with its white and sometimes yellow wide curl sand dunes that vanish off in the ocean crashing waves and strong currents. Wrecks of boats make you think of the frequent travelers of the airmail. Mirleft still a nice little place to hole up for a cup of mint Tea, walking the dusty street and enjoying a carefree atmosphere. Then we continue via Tiznit the clean, neat and tidy, and the good staging point en route to Agadir, the city that was completely rebuilt following a devastating earthquake in 1960, with its busy port and beach resort sprawling beneath its Kasbah. All of which combine to make it worth an excellent stopover en route to Essaouira.

We leave the city that spreads over a large area, both along the coast and inland from the huge swath of beach. We will continue Driving north by the Atlantic ocean. There are sandy coves every few kilometres, and welcoming eateries make it a good road to take break in from time to time. After 12km and 14km we will pass by Aourir and Taghazout, Morocco’s number-one surfing resort. A short way from here located the wild beach of Sidi Kaouki a chilled escape from Essaouira and one of Morocco’s top wind-surfing and surfing spot. It’s not for faint-hearted. Later we reach the sleepy Berber village of Diabat that was once a dope-smoking colony popular with hippies. Another 5km we get into the beautifully named Essaouira with its light and beauty that have forever attracted Artist.

If you could not explore Essaouira the previous day, you still have time for that today. You have a free morning to explore Jimi Hendrix’s town today before you head to Marrakech. After having your breakfast you’re free to roam in the city that was once and still a heaven for hippie backpackers and Gnawa musicians. You can book a local guide, if not you can start your visit by the ramparts a series of forts that were built in the 15th century around the Medina of Mogador. Inside the Medina you’ll have a chance to visit The Mellah (former Jewish quarter), the Morocco’s 3rd fishing port where you can have a delicious fish meal. Afternoon you will head to Marrakech, and in your way towards the Red city, if you’re lucky you will have a chance to see the tree goats’ phenomenon. To arrive in Marrakech to drop quickly your baggage at the hotel and join the carnival night of the crazed cacophony of musicians, snake charmers and vendors in the open-air famed Jemaa El-Fnaa square.

With your private Marrakech born and bred guide, you embark exploring the Red City from its old part with its Medina’s skinny lanes that leads to lavish sites, tombs and religious monuments decked out in marble. Bahia and El-Badii Palace and Saadien’s Tombs will be your targets. Afterward, your driver/Tour Guide will pick you up for the outside medina visit to explore the Majorelle Garden, Museum Saint Laurent, Berber Museum. While in Marrakech you will surely encounter thousands of motorcyclists and horse-carts roaming in the city and some of them pull over next the vast square of Jemaa El-Fnaa where it’s carnival night every night and musicians, acrobats, storytellers and slapstick acting troupes tap into the Medina frenetic pulse.

Airport Shuttle You will be departing Morocco today. Pack you bags and make sure that your Morocco tour’s pictures are well-saved. we hope that you have taken some unique and beautiful pictures here in Morocco. You driver/tour guide will be waiting to drive you to your aiport either in Marrakech.

tourName: Morocco highlights holiday, with added comfort
generalInfo: Take in the rich history and diverse culture of Morocco on an nine-day Premium adventure. Marvel at the Mosque of Hassan II in Casablanca, discover the enchanting medina of Meknes, uncover ancient history at the Roman ruins of Volubilis, wander mazelike alleys in Fes el-Bali, relax in the lakeside settlement of Bin el-Ouidane, watch sunset from your desert camp in Agafay and watch Djemaa el-Fna come to life in Marrakech. Experience life in the Middle Atlas Mountains, share stories and food with a local family in Fes, travel with a local leader and gain unrivalled insight into the Moroccan way of life.

dayInfo.title: Casablanca.
dayInfo.description: Salaam Alaikum! Welcome to Morocco. When you arrive at Casablanca Airport, you’ll be met by a local representative and transferred to your hotel. Your adventure begins with a welcome meeting at 6 pm. If you arrive with time to spare, maybe visit the Villa des Arts. This gorgeous Art Deco gallery holds numerous exhibitions of contemporary Moroccan and international art. If you’re looking for a different type of cultural experience, you can also visit the Museum of Judaism. Tonight, celebrate the beginning of a new adventure over dinner with your group, trying classic dishes like tagine and couscous.

dayInfo.title: Fes.
dayInfo.description: This morning, you’ll visit one of the most impressive sites in Casablanca – the mighty Mosque of Hassan II. Second only in size to the great mosque at Mecca, the huge building sits partly on land and partly over sea and is one of the only religious sites open to non-Muslims. Later, leave Casablanca and drive to Meknes, where you’ll explore the charming streets of the medina – the old walled section of the city. Drive on to the mosaic-filled Roman ruins of Volubilis, where a local guide will show you around and help you imagine the bustling city that once was. Enjoy a picnic lunch of fresh bread, cheese, seasonal fruits and olives from the market. In the late afternoon, continue to Fes, your home for the next two nights.

dayInfo.title: Fes.
dayInfo.description: Today, you’ll discover Fes’s huge, well-preserved medieval Old City and medina on a morning walking tour with your leader. Wander through the twisting streets and alleyways and explore the speciality sections that divide the souq as your leader talks you through the local customs and traditions. Pass historic khans, dye pits and stalls, then take a break from the hustle and bustle at a family-owned tea house before a visit to the ornate inner courtyards of the Islamic school El-Attarine Madrasa and Funduq al-Najjarin – an 18th-century inn. You’ll then have a free afternoon before dinner tonight, where you'll be warmly welcomed into the home-turned-restaurant of a local family for a pastilla dinner in a private after-hours experience. Learn how the iconic Moroccan pie is made as you chat with your friendly hosts about life in Fes.

dayInfo.title: Bine el Ouidane.
dayInfo.description: Travel from Fes to Bine el Ouidane, with plenty of breaks along the way to appreciate the ever-changing Moroccan landscape. Today is a bit of a long travel day, so it's a good idea to get stuck into your book or favourite podcasts. Bine el Ouidane is a small settlement perfectly placed on the bank of the lake, surrounded by sheer rocks. Your Feature Stay accommodation for the night sits at the foot of the Atlas Mountains, on the edge of the huge lake. Maybe spend your afternoon soaking up the calm surroundings in the swimming pool or kick back with a drink on the terrace.

dayInfo.title: Bine el Ouidane.
dayInfo.description: Today you’ll head out onto the water, hopping in a small boat to see more of the turquoise lake and surrounding rocky gorges. Float over the water and take in the views. Then, head to the house of a local farming family in the village that sits on the lake. Have a cup of tea as the family shares their stories on farming in Morocco and what their life is like here. You’ll also be treated to a home-cooked lunch, before heading back to the hotel for a free evening. Maybe lounge by the infinity pool, hike the surrounding mountain trails or treat yourself to a rejuvenating massage or jacuzzi session at the health spa.

dayInfo.title: Agafay.
dayInfo.description: Today you’ll make your way to Agafay – a red-rock desert in the South of Marrakech. Along the way, stop at Ouzoud Falls – a collective name for several waterfalls in Azilal, which all flow into the El-Abid River’s gorge. Take in the immensity of the cascades, then continue on to the rolling landscape of the desert. Arrive at your desert camp in the late afternoon, freshen up in your tents, then head out to catch the sunset as it lights up the horizon. If you like, you can also take part in an optional camel riding experience here. Later, have dinner at camp then be treated to a stargazing experience, as an English-speaking guide points out the constellations and planets above.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech.
dayInfo.description: Wake up early this morning to catch the sunrise over the desert. After breakfast, you’ll then travel to Marrakech. When you arrive, head out on an orientation walk with your leader to the great square of Djemaa el-Fna – one of the largest public spaces in the world and the city's most iconic landmark. As day turns to night, the square transforms into a hive of activity. Once you’ve got your bearings, the rest of the evening is yours to explore at your own pace. Maybe have dinner on one of the restaurant balconies overlooking the humming square with views of the Koutoubia Mosque.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech.
dayInfo.description: After breakfast today, meet your local guide and set off on a morning tour of the old medina, through the bustling souks that are the lifeblood of the city. Explore courtyards filled with the scent of orange blossom and the many salons and chambers that make up Bahia Palace. Stop by the Koutoubia Mosque – the inside is for Muslims only, but the famous minaret is a sight to behold. Walk back through the streets of the old medina to Djemaa el-Fna. The food here is best experienced like a local, so be sure to bring your appetite as your local guide will take you for a tasting session where you’ll try a range of seasonal delights like freshly squeezed orange juice and fried Moroccan donuts. The rest of the day is free. Maybe visit Le Jardin Secret – a traditional medina garden with a magnificent courtyard – or head back into the medina and practice your haggling skills.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech.
dayInfo.description: Your trip ends today after breakfast. If you would like to stay longer, just speak to your booking agent ahead of time.

generalInfo:
This 12 days private luxury tour of Morocco is designed to provide you with a luxurious and immersive experience, combining cultural exploration, culinary delights, and stunning landscapes and Sahara desert. Experience the finest in Moroccan hospitality as you stay in carefully selected authentic and boutique accommodations. Embark on a journey of discovery as you explore Morocco's rich cultural heritage, guided tours by knowledgeable local experts will take you through the winding streets of ancient medinas of imperial cities, allowing you to marvel at architectural wonders, vibrant souks, and historic landmarks. Embark on a culinary journey through Morocco, indulging in traditional dishes such as fragrant tagines and flavorful couscous. Delight in sumptuous meals at renowned local restaurants, sampling a variety of delicious flavors. Discover the vibrant food scene of Marrakesh on a foodie tour, tantalizing your taste buds with exotic spices and fresh street food. Immerse yourself in the local culture with a hands-on cooking class, where you'll learn to prepare authentic Moroccan delicacies and unlock the secrets of this rich culinary tradition.
Embark on a captivating journey through Morocco's diverse landscapes, from the majestic Atlas Mountains and the blue-washed streets of Chefchaouen to the enchanting medinas of Marrakech and Fes, and the ancient marvels of Ait Benhaddou. Travel through picturesque valleys, terraced fields, and charming Berber villages in the Atlas Mountains, and experience the magic of the Sahara Desert with thrilling 4WD adventure, camel ride and nights under starry skies. Immerse yourself in the vibrant culture, savoring traditional cuisine, exploring bustling souks, and discovering architectural wonders. This unforgettable adventure will leave you amazed by the beauty and richness of Morocco's landscapes and cultural heritage.

dayInfo.description: Casablanca - Welcome to Morocco! On arrival to Casablanca airport, you’ll be greeted by your tour leader and transferred to your accommodation in Casablanca. Your adventure will start with a welcome meeting with your tour leader. Casablanca is the economic capital of Morocco. Modern infrastructures are in the middle of its charming districts, between Arab-Muslim heritage and legacies of the colonial period. Visit Hassan II Mosque one of the impressive mosques in the world. It is the second largest functioning mosque in Africa and is the 7th largest in the world. It is the only mosque in Morocco that welcome non-Muslim to visit its inside and it is splendid architecture built on water. Tonight, enjoy Moroccan dinner at Riad style restaurant where you’ll enjoy traditional dishes and Moroccan warm hospitality

Rabat - Today travel to Rabat the capital of Morocco, where you will visit Rabat old medina, listed as a World Heritage Site, on arrival visit the Royal Palace (from the outside) and the vast minaret Hassan Tower that it is the Mohammed V Mausoleum. Free time and Overnight in your Riad in Rabat.

Chefchaouen - Today after breakfast travel to the isolated town of Chefchaouen. on arrival check in and free time to explore this beautiful town. Chefchaouen, or the ‘blue city’, is arguably one of the prettiest places in Morocco. Set against a wide valley and nestled between two peaks in the stunning Rif Mountains, Chefchaouen may take you by surprise. Its medina has been lovingly cared for with striking blue and whitewashed houses, red-tiled roofs and artistic doorways. Much of Chefchaouen was recreated by Andalusian refugees escaping the Reconquistia, so you might feel like you're in the hills of Spain while exploring its streets. Ease into the relaxed pace of life in this rural retreat.

Chefchaouen - Today take a guided tour of the sights, sounds, and smells of the medina and sample the delicious local goat cheese at a cafe in the Plaza Uta el-Hammam. Admire the architecture of the 15th-century Grand Mosque (closed to non-Muslims) and browse the shops in the square selling woven goods and small sweets. Also within the plaza is the walled fortress of the Kasbah. Wander through the tranquil gardens inside, check out the ethnographic museum and soak in wonderful views from the rooftop. after the tour, enjoy optional lunch at the authentic restaurant Café clock with amazing views on Chefchaouen medina. balance of the day is at leisure.

Fes - Today you'll travel to Moulay Idriss the sacred pilgrimage site in the foothills of the Rif Mountains. The town is named after Moulay Idriss I, the founder of the Idrisid dynasty and the first Islamic ruler of Morocco. He is highly revered in the country, and his mausoleum is a major attraction in Moulay Idriss. The mausoleum is a sacred site where visitors and locals come to pay their respects and seek blessings. On arrival, enjoy walking tour of the old town and have lunch at local guesthouse. Afterwards, visit the World Heritage-listed Volubilis was once a provincial Roman capital, a distant outpost of the empire, and the remains make an undeniably impressive sight. When it was damaged by an earthquake in the 18th century, much of the marble was taken for construction in nearby Meknes. Upon arrival, take a tour around the ruins with a local guide. Please remember to pack drinking water, hat, sunglasses and sun cream for this tour as it may get hot and you will be exposed to the sun. And, of course, don’t forget to take your camera as the town is filled with fantastic mosaics along the Decumanus Maximus, many of which remain intact. After time spent imagining Volubilis as the bustling city it once was, continue to the the living museum of Fes for 2 nights. Tonight have a delicious dinner at local restaurant where you'll enjoy one of Moroccan specialties of Fes of harira (chickpea soup) and chicken-stuffed pastilla and couscous.

Fes - Fes is the spiritual and cultural heart of Morocco; vibrant, noisy, fascinating and overwhelming – a visual and pungent feast for the senses. It is made up of three distinct ‘cities’, or quarters. Today head into the old city, known locally as Fes el Bali, arguably the world's most fascinating and confounding old city. Medieval Fes was one of the world's great centers of education and culture, both Islamic and Jewish. Its religious institutions and libraries are legendary, its mosques of great renown. And it was to Fes that many of the Muslims (and Jews) expelled from Spain by Ferdinand and Isabella came in 1492. Walk through the twisting streets and alleyways, passing donkeys piled high with goods, and explore the specialty sections that divide the souk. Filled with historic khans, medresses and dye-pits, stalls loaded with fruits, herbs and soups and smell of spice and sound of hammering of copper fills the air, it’s not hard to imagine yourself back in the Middle Ages. Spend the day exploring the old city, visiting Medresse el Attarine, the tanneries and the splendid Funduk Nejjarine, a beautifully restored 18th century inn. During the guided tour you'll enjoy Fes local street food and indulge in a variety of delicious Moroccan dishes. Fes is renowned for its rich gastronomy, blending traditional flavors, aromatic spices, and unique cooking techniques. Explore the vibrant food markets of Fes, such as Bab Boujloud and Place R'cif. Immerse yourself in the bustling atmosphere and discover a wide array of fresh produce, aromatic spices, dried fruits, and Moroccan specialties. Engage with local vendors, learn about their ingredients. You'll finish the tour by the late afternoon and free time to relax and enjoy sunset drink at one of Fes's beautiful terraces.

Merzouga - Today it's an eight-hour drive towards the mighty Sahara Desert. Since you'll have the convenience of our own private minivan, there will be many opportunities to stop and admire views of Kasbahs and palmeries (valleys lush with date palms, fields and orchards) along the way. Drive through changing scenery, from barren mountainsides to fertile valleys, pausing in Midelt to strech your legs. Continue through the Ziz Valley, one of the largest oases in Morocco, dotted with palm groves and small villages. Finally, you'll reach the town of Erfoud, the gateway to the Sahara where you'll jump on your 4WD ride for a spectacular drive to your camp in the middle of the Sahara Desert. Tonight enjoy an authentic Moroccan dining experience, with delicious and local dishes before gathering around the campfire, where local musicians perform traditional music and dance. This is a great opportunity to relax and unwind after a long day and to enjoy the tranquility and beauty of the Sahara under the starry night sky. Finally, you'll reach the town of Erfoud, the gateway to the Sahara where you'll jump on your 4WD ride for a spectacular drive to your camp in the middle of the Sahara Desert. Tonight enjoy an authentic Moroccan dining experience, with delicious and local dishes before gathering around the campfire, where local musicians perform traditional music and dance. This is a great opportunity to relax and unwind after a long day and to enjoy the tranquility and beauty of the Sahara under the starry night sky.

Merzouga - Today jump on 4WD ride to discover deep Sahara desert where you'll visit an oasis local farm where you would feel just as if you were in a dream, continue to the seasonal lake that is a popular destination for migratory birds, Afterwards drive to visit the Gnawa village called Khamlia for Madfouna lunch known as Berber Pizza. Khamlia is a small village nearby Merzouga main town. The uniqueness of this village stands at the fact that all its inhabitants are black Africans, but speak Berber as their mother tongue. They were taken from Mali, Sudan and Senegal, and displaced to Morocco centuries ago. The inhabitants brought with them the folkloric aspect of their life as embodied through the Gnawa music where you’ll have the opportunity to witness one of their musical show. After lunch drive back to your camp to relax and prepare for sunset camel ride. The Erg Chebbi dunes are the most stunning in the country and an essential part of any visit to Morocco. An erg is a vast sea of shifting wind-swept sand that's formed into picturesque, undulating crests and valleys. Located at the end of a sealed road and just 20 kilometers from the Algerian border, this really feels like frontier country. Enjoy dinner and campfire ambiance for the last night in Sahara.

Ait Benhaddou - Start the day with a truly unforgettable experience sunrise over the dunes, watching the landscape turn remarkable shades of orange. After breakfast, drive to Todra Gorge, an impressive natural trench that rises over 250 meters, offering one of Morocco's most spectacular sights. Then, continue your journey to the Skoura Oasis, known for its private kasbahs, including the ornate Kasbah Ameridhl with mud-brick walls. Next, head to Ait Benhaddou, a historic hilltop village that has remained largely unchanged since the 11th century. It's famous for its beautiful kasbah and has been featured in films like Lawrence of Arabia, Game of Thrones, and Gladiator. Wrap up your day with a pleasant dinner at your riad.

Marrakech - After breakfast, enjoy a walk through the winding streets of old town, making your way to the top of the hill, from where you can enjoy the views across the surrounding plains. Descend back from Kasbah to finish with tea and Moroccan pastries break at local tea house run only by local women created by non-profit association to support and create jobs opportunities for local women. After your break, drive for five hours through the winding roads of the Atlas, bound for red city Marrakech for the night. check in and relax before you embark on an evening private street food tour where you’ll get the chance to eat like a local and sample specialties that many visitors miss from harira soup, Tanjia, Moroccan pancakes Mssemen, Sfan, lamb kefta to spiced Moroccan tea while walking through the ancient medina of Marrakech and capturing its magic at night.

Marrakech - Today join your local chef for a hands on cooking class in a beautiful traditional Moroccan kitchen and you'll be guided through the preparation of a variety of dishes. You will begin the class by learning about the ingredients and spices used in Moroccan cooking. The chef will explain the history and cultural significance of each ingredient and show you how to properly prepare them. Next, you will have the opportunity to prepare several Moroccan dishes, such as tagine, couscous, or pastilla. You will work alongside the chef to chop, mix, and cook the ingredients. After the cooking is complete, you will sit down to enjoy the fruits of your labor. You will be able to taste all the dishes you prepared, accompanied by traditional Moroccan bread and a refreshing mint tea. Enjoy some free time before you meet your local guide to discover the greatness & history of this site and its main monuments. Your first stop will be the famous Koutoubia Mosque. Its minaret is the prototype for others of its kind around the world, including La Giralda in Seville. Then, pass by the royal palace to the Ancient Kasbah. Admire the beauty of Moroccan architecture, walk by the Jewish Mellah streets before arriving to the beautiful Bahia Palace. Explore peaceful courtyards filled with the scent of orange blossom and the many lounges and rooms that make up for this architectural wonder. Continue to the amazing Secret Garden, the garden is is part of the great tradition of stately Arab-Andalusian and Moroccan palaces. It was recent renovated, so nowadays, visitors can appreciate and discover its gardens and buildings, which are outstanding examples of Islamic art and architecture. Afterwards, you will head back through the narrow streets of the Medina through souks and spice markets where you might want to shop a few souvenirs once you arrive at the Rahba square. Tonight, finish this amazing adventure with farewell dinner at Comptoir Darna a chic and exotic decorated restaurant with belly dancing shows offering Moroccan & international gastronomic cuisine.

Departure day Marrakesh. Today enjoy your last breakfast in Morocco. With no activities planned for today, you are free to leave at any time. Check-out time is usually around midday, however, if you wish to spend more time in Marrakesh or visit the Atlas Mountains or the coastal city Essaouira, we can help you with organizing more time in Morocco. Your transfer to Marrakech airport will be arranged. Pick up is three hour prior your flight departure time.

generalInfo:
Embark on this captivating adventure through Morocco with our specially curated itinerary.
From the vibrant streets of Marrakech to the awe-inspiring landscapes of the High Atlas Mountains and the serene coastal charm of Essaouira, this journey is your gateway to an unforgettable adventure!
Allow us to introduce you to the heart and soul of this captivating country, where history, culture, and natural beauty meet.

Marrakech: A Sensory Extravaganza
Your Moroccan journey begins in Marrakech, a city that weaves the past and the present seamlessly. Your stay here promises not only comfort but an opportunity to immerse yourself in the local culture. Step into the shoes of a local as you partake in a mesmerizing cooking class, crafting traditional Moroccan dishes using the freshest ingredients which you will source with a guide from the market, opening your eyes to the kaleidoscope of spices, textiles, and treasures that makes Marrakech a shopper's paradise.

High Atlas Mountains: Nature's Grandeur
Leaving the city behind, venture into the serene beauty of the High Atlas Mountains, specifically Imlil. Here, a delightful lunch awaits you at a local house, offering an authentic taste of Moroccan hospitality. A guided walk through the region's striking landscapes will reveal the hidden secrets of the Atlas Mountains and its charming Berber villages. The panoramic vistas and tranquil surroundings will leave you spellbound.

Ouarzazate: The Gateway to the Sahara
The journey continues to Ouarzazate, known as the "Gateway to the Sahara." You'll experience the breath-taking beauty of the desert in a deluxe Bivouac, where luxury meets the mystique of the dunes. As the sun sets, a camel ride will take you to a vantage point where you can watch the mesmerizing desert sunset, a moment of profound tranquillity.

Kasbah of Ait Benhaddou: A UNESCO Gem
A 4x4 adventure ride will take you to the UNESCO-listed Kasbah of Ait Benhaddou, an ancient fortified village with a history dating back centuries. This remarkable site, with its intricate mud-brick architecture, will transport you back in time, offering an insight into Morocco's rich heritage.

Essaouira: Coastal Charms
The final destination of your journey is the coastal town of Essaouira, where the captivating blend of Moorish and European influences creates a unique atmosphere. Stroll along the picturesque seaside promenade, relax on sandy beaches, and explore the city's UNESCO-listed medina. Here, history and natural beauty intertwine, offering an ideal conclusion to your Moroccan adventure.

This journey encapsulates the essence of Morocco, taking you on an extraordinary voyage that spans landscapes, culture, and history. Prepare to be captivated by the wonders of this North African gem and create lasting memories that will stay with you forever. Morocco awaits your exploration, and with our expertly designed itinerary, you can rest assured that every moment will be a treasure to cherish.

dayInfo.description: Arrival at Marrakech Airport – Transfer to your Riad in Marrakech.

Morning Guide Visit in Marrakech. The remainder of the day is yours to venture out to the amazing hectic Jemaa El Fna square, a magical sight that comes alive after the sun goes down with all the sights, smells and sounds! For dinner, feel free to try one of the outdoor food stalls which offer a variety of local food or one of the many amazing rooftop restaurants in Marrakech. Be sure to pre-book as some of them are very popular! We have a great list we can recommend for you.

A cooking class with shopping in the souk a awaits you, an opportunity to dive deep in to the Moroccan cuisine and spices! Afternoon is at your leisure to relax at the Riad or take in a spot of shopping in the Souk.
Day excursion to the high Atlas Mountains, Imlil: lunch at a local house & a guided walk are included.

Depart Marrakech for your private transfer to Ouarzazate, Hollywood of the Sahara! Ouarzazate has earned the nickname "Hollywood of the Sahara" due to its popularity as a filming location for many Hollywood and international film productions. It has been the backdrop for famous movies and TV series, including "Lawrence of Arabia," "Gladiator," "Game of Thrones," and "The Mummy."

Leave Ouarzazate to head to the Desert. First stay is in Erg Lihoudi. Erg Lihoudi offers a unique opportunity to immerse yourself in the beauty and tranquillity of the Sahara Desert while exploring a less-travelled part of Morocco's vast desert landscape. It's a destination that beckons adventurers and nature enthusiasts alike. Stay overnight in a deluxe Bivouac and enjoy a camel ride to watch the sunset.

Continue your adventure in the desert by 4x4 and travel to Erg Cheggaga. Erg Chegaga, also known as Chegaga Dunes or Chigaga Dunes, is one of the most remote and pristine desert destinations in Morocco. Located in the south-eastern part of the country, it is one of the two largest Saharan ergs (sand seas) in Morocco, with the other being Erg Chebbi near Merzouga. Overnight stay in a deluxe bivouac.

Enjoy an early breakfast or last magical sunrise before your 4X4 transfers back to Zagora to meet the driver and travel to Ait Benhaddou. Overnight stay near the Kasbah of Ait Benhaddou. Aït Benhaddou, a well-preserved Kasbah, is a must-visit attraction. It is a UNESCO World Heritage site and a remarkable example of traditional Moroccan architecture.

From one UNESCO heritage to another one in the old Mogador of Essaouira. Travel by private transfer to your Riad. Essaouira is a city with a fascinating history. It was originally known as Mogador and was founded by the Phoenicians. The city has been influenced by various cultures over the centuries, including Portuguese, French, and Berber, contributing to its unique architectural and cultural blend.

Free day to explore more of Essaouira. UNESCO World Heritage Site: The historic medina of Essaouira was designated as a UNESCO World Heritage site in 2001, recognizing its well-preserved and harmonious architectural ensemble. The medina's distinctive blue and white buildings, fortified walls, and narrow winding streets are a sight to behold. Coastal Beauty: Essaouira is known for its stunning coastal beauty. The city is situated on the Atlantic Ocean, and its long sandy beaches are popular for swimming, windsurfing, and kite-surfing. The sea breeze provides a refreshing escape from the Moroccan heat. Mogador Island: Located just off the coast of Essaouira, Mogador Island is a nature reserve and home to various bird species, including the rare Eleanora's falcon. The island is accessible by boat and offers opportunities for bird-watching and exploration. Historic Medina: The medina of Essaouira is a labyrinth of narrow streets, colorful souks, and artisan workshops. It's a fantastic place to shop for local crafts, including traditional Moroccan rugs, jewelry, woodwork, and textiles. Fish Market: Essaouira is renowned for its bustling fish market, where local fishermen bring in their daily catches. Visitors can experience the vibrant atmosphere and even sample freshly grilled seafood right on the spot. Music and Arts Scene: Essaouira is famous for its artistic and cultural heritage. The city hosts various music festivals, including the Gnaoua World Music Festival, which celebrates the Gnaoua and World Music fusion. Many art galleries and workshops showcase the talent of local and international artists. Fortified Walls: The city's walls and bastions, designed by a French architect during the 18th century, offer panoramic views of the city and the ocean. They were built to protect Essaouira from attacks by pirates and foreign powers. Gnaoua Culture: Essaouira is a stronghold of Gnaoua culture, a spiritual and musical tradition that blends African, Arab, and Berber elements. You can often hear the mesmerizing sounds of Gnaoua music in the streets and cafes. Relaxed Atmosphere: Compared to bustling Moroccan cities like Marrakech and Fes, Essaouira has a more relaxed and laid-back atmosphere. The city's seaside ambiance, with its fresh sea air and slower pace, makes it an ideal destination for a peaceful retreat.
Explore Essaouira or simply relax at the Riad.
Unfortunately, your stay in Morocco has come to an end, time for your private transfer to Marrakech Airport.
