Departure of Morocco 9 Days Tour from Marrakech takes place in front of your hotel or Riad. Through Tizi- N-Tichka pass (2260m) in the High Atlas Mountains. You will enjoy a snaky road, beautiful landscapes with different colors and Berber villages along the way. The first pause will be in AIT BARKA VILLAGE. It will be around 10:00AM to take beautiful pictures; relax of the car and have breakfast if you wish it. It’s a point to start the highest atlas mountains of Morocco TIZI N TICHKA. The second pause will take place in the top of TICHKA. Arriving to AIT BEN HADOU! It is classified by UNESCO as a first world heritage. Here you will be guided by local guide to explain the history of this amazing heritage AIT BEN HADOU. Then you will have free time for lunch and it will be around one hour. You will continue via Ouarzazate, the rose valley, Skoura palm grove to Dades valley and gorges. The first night will be in a Moroccan typical hotel, located in the heart of Dades gorges at the south of Morocco. Dinner, Breakfast and overnight in Dades gorges are included.

Departure from your hotel in Dades gorges after a typical Moroccan breakfast. Taking the road of 1000 Kasbahs driving around the colorful Berber villages of Dades valley. 45 km further, you will get to Tineghir. It is famous by its beautiful palm groves and Jewish quarter. While arriving Todra gorges (Todgha) its free time to go on trek along the canyons about 300 m high. It’s a preferred place by mountain climbers. Afterwards you will leave to Erg Chebbi dunes in Merzouga Sahara desert. Then it’s free time for lunch on the way before you arrive to Erfoud. Once you arrive to the dunes of Erg Chebbi, you will take a camel ride for 1h30 at the sunset to get to the oasis where the camp is located. Spend the night in the bivouac in Merzouga Sahara dunes under nomadic tents or outside under shooting stars. Play drums with the camel drivers. Dinner and overnight in Merzouga Sahara desert camp.

Today you will have to wake up very early in the morning to see what will may be the best sunrise of your life. You will set over the Sand Dunes of Sahara of Erg Chebbi to watch wonderful sunrise. After watching the sunrise you will go down to the Camp for breakfast. Then you’ll peacefully camel-trek back to the village of Merzouga. While enjoying morning camel ride you couldn’t fail to appreciate the unique beauty of the spectacular Erg Chebbi sand dunes – changing with the light as the day progresses. Once you arrive the village of Merzouga, you will meet the driver again to continue the tour to Fes. You will pass by the beautiful Ziz valley, Errachidia and Midelt where you will have free time to have lunch at the local restaurant. On the afternoon; after lunch you will continue the tour to the Cedar Forest where we will stop to visit the famous wild monkeys then to Ifran city. Overnight at the Hotel/Riad in Fes.

After breakfast in your Riad, you will start exploring the oldest city in Morocco “Fes”. Fes is so rich in culture, traditions and gastronomy. It is referred in Morocco as the country’s capital culture. This tour will let you walk in its oldest medieval Medina, its alleys and small streets. You will visit the Royal Palace gate, the Blue Gate and the Jewish quarter, the first Mellah ever built in Morocco, built during the 14th century. You will enjoy best sites with cultural and historical interest including the famous Al Qaraouine University, the oldest one in the world, the Tanneries and Moulay Idriss mausoleum. After lunch, you will visit the tiles cooperative and then experience a wonderful panoramic view over the whole Medina of Fes. Overnight at the same Riad.

Early in the morning we head to Chefchaouen through the Rif Mountains to enjoy the views of the Magic Mountains till we get Chefchaouen one of the stunning villages in the feet of Rif Mountains. Chefchaouen or Chaouen, as it is often called by Moroccans, is a popular tourist destination because of its proximity to Tangier and the Spanish enclave of Ceuta. The name refers to the shape of the mountain tops above the town, that look like the two horns (chaoua) of a goat. « Chef Chaouen » derives from the Berber word for horns, Ichawen. There are approximately two hundred hotels catering to the summer influx of European tourists. One distinction possessed by Chefchaouen is its blue-rinsed houses and buildings. Chefchaouen is a popular shopping destination as well, as it offers many native handicrafts that are not available elsewhere in Morocco, such as wool garments and woven blankets. The goat cheese native to the area is also popular with tourists. The growing tourist industry is geared especially towards Spanish tourists, who are especially numerous during great Catholic feasts like Semana Santa and Christmas. Chefchaouen was visited by Joe Orton and Kenneth Halliwell in 1967. They adored it finding it « very ‘Golden Bough-ish’ Orton mentions their trip in the Orton Diaries. There are a number of distinct mosques in the town. Aside from the mosque at Place Uta Hammam in the medina, there is also a mosque dedicated to the patron saint of Northern Morocco’s Jebalah region, Moulay Abdeslam Ben Mchich Alami. His tomb and the village surrounding it is by the way an hour’s drive or so from Chefchaouen on the old road to Larache. There is also a ruined mosque built by the Spanish, with stairs still in the tower.

After Breakfast in your hotel you will have some free time then we travel to the Capital of Morocco Rabat. Where you will visit the Kasbah of the Udayas and the Bab Chellah then to the Hassan Tower after lunch then we continue our trip to Casablanca after one hour driver then we get the Casablanca and Check in to your hotel.
Transfer to Marrakech airport following your flight departure time.

placesVisited: Fez, Marrakech, Rabat, scenic train journeys, Optional activities include: cooking classes, hiking excursions, train rides to Meknes, drives into the High Atlas Mountains and day trips to Essaouira
generalInfo:
Morocco by Rail
A stylish journey through imperial cities, with first-class train travel and private guided discovery

Experience the romance and rhythm of Morocco on this seamless and sophisticated holiday by rail, connecting the country’s most captivating cities with comfort, elegance and ease. With first-class train travel, private transfers, and expert-led city tours included throughout, this journey blends rich cultural immersion with relaxed, well-paced travel.

If you fancy clambering aboard the ‘Marrakech Express’ then this Morocco rail holiday lets you do just that with overnight stays in Marrakech, Morocco's capital (Rabat) and Fez giving travellers a real insight into the scenery and lifestyles across the north of the country. Unique, romantic and always exciting, travelling through Morocco by train is a reliable means of experiencing an ever-changing landscape in comfort with excursions possible to Meknes, Volubilis, Casablanca, the Atlas Mountains and Essaouira - all available upon request.

Your adventure begins in Marrakech, where you’ll stay in a beautifully restored riad nestled within the medina’s winding alleyways. Step into a world of carved cedar, mosaic courtyards and rooftop terraces, offering a tranquil haven in the heart of the city. During your private guided tour, uncover Marrakech’s iconic landmarks — from the opulence of the Bahia Palace to the vibrant souks, serene gardens, and the ever-buzzing Djemaa el-Fna. Chic cafés and rooftop restaurants align market places and thriving squares where the mix of mystery, history and cultural enlightenment combine to wondrous effect.

From here, board a first-class train to Morocco’s refined capital, Rabat. With its palm-lined boulevards, Andalusian gardens and elegant colonial architecture, Rabat offers a calm sophistication rarely found elsewhere. Your private guide will lead you through the city’s highlights, including the Kasbah of the Udayas, the impressive Hassan Tower, the necropolis at Chellah and the grand mausoleum of the Kings.

Continue by rail to the spiritual and cultural heart of Morocco, the city of Fez. Lose yourself in the medieval maze of the Fez el-Bali medina, a UNESCO World Heritage site where artisans still practise centuries-old crafts. During your privately guided visit, discover the Al-Qarawiyyin Mosque, the tanneries, and hidden riads and madrasas that bring the city’s layered history vividly to life.

Optional detours by train can also take you to Casablanca, where the grandeur of the Hassan II Mosque meets the modern buzz of Morocco’s commercial capital, or to Tangier, a coastal city of cosmopolitan flair with sweeping views of the Strait of Gibraltar. Both can be tailored into your itinerary, with private transfers and expert-led city tours included.

Throughout your journey, you'll travel comfortably between cities on first-class ONCF trains, with all logistics and transfers arranged for you. Handpicked riads and boutique hotels offer character and comfort, while private guides ensure a deeper connection to each destination.

This is Morocco in motion — elegant, enriching, and effortlessly enjoyable. Whether wandering the labyrinthine streets of Fez or sipping mint tea on a sunlit terrace in Rabat, this holiday is designed for the traveller who values both cultural depth and refined travel.

Information worth knowing:
We’ve included all train and overland transfers to and from your riad or hotel within the overall tour price.

Private guided sightseeing tours are included, along with free time to explore and opportunities for optional activities, such as: hiking or cookery classes. Helping to give travellers a well-rounded picture of Morocco this holiday comes with great rail connections and pre-booked tickets aiding safe travels with the minimum of fuss.

All of the guided city tours are accompanied by an English-speaking guide and include transportation, entry costs, and a tour of the souks and main points of the medinas.

The riad accommodation that we’ve selected is typical to Morocco and features an internal courtyard that’s pivotal to the character, the comfort and the lifestyles of local people. These riads have been carefully converted from private family homes to fine guest houses where local staff are just as integral to the overall experience as the locally sourced produce used in the kitchen.

dayInfo.description: Welcome to Marrakech. Arrive at the airport and transfer to your choice of B&B riad accommodation which will become your home for the next three nights. The rest of the day is yours to explore in and around Marrakech at leisure. Optional Street Food Tour recommended.
Today you'll be invited to explore the city of Marrakech, firstly on a guided tour and then, for the rest of the day, under your own steam.

Your third day in Marrakech is yours to do with as you wish with several optional activities, such as: cooking classes, hiking trips and drives into the High Atlas Mountains or along the coast to Essaouira, all easily accessible.

Today you'll bid Marrakech adieu as you transfer by taxi to the train station and make the four hour journey to the capital of Morocco, Rabat. Upon arrival in Rabat you'll transfer to your preferred riad or B&B accommodation before having the rest of the day free for exploring and sightseeing.

Optional city tour of Rabat in the morning or free time. Another train journey today takes you from Rabat to the ancient walled citadel of Fez where you'll check into your choice of B&B hotel which will become your home for the next three nights.
Enjoy the morning sightseeing in Fez before spending the rest of the day exploring amongst the markets and narrow alleyways at your leisure.
Today you can continue your exploration of northern Morocco with our private guided tour of Meknes, Volubilis and Moulay Idriss. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

Say farewell to Fez before transferring to the local airport. OR, alternatively, taking the train back to Marrakech for another night before departing on your scheduled flight from Marrakech airport on Day 9.

tourName: Sahara Desert and Anti Atlas mountain tour
generalInfo: This wonderful and unique tour will allow you to discover Anti-Atlas and Sahara Desert of Morocco including, Kasbahs, Draa Valley, Erg Chegag Dunes, Agadir and Essaouira.

dayInfo.description: Our professional driver will welcome you to Morocco and pick you up from the airport of Marrakech. He will wait for you in the exit of the airport with a sign with your name. He will transfer you to your Hotel / Riad in Marrakech. Overnight in the Hotel / Riad.

Our driver will pick you up after breakfast in your Riad / Hotel in Marrakech and start the trip. You will have various stops in the high Atlas Mountains to see Berber villages and amazing landscapes. Ait Ben Hadou village is well known for its remarkable Kasbah, used in many world prominent films, like Game of Thrones and Lawrence of Arabia. After the visit of the Kasbah Ait Ben Hadou you will continue to Ouarzazate where you will spend the night. Overnight in the Hotel / Riad in Ouarzazate.

In the morning after breakfast you'll travel to the Sahara Desert and Erg Chegaga. Today you will pass by the Anti-Atlas Mountains and the Draa Valley and its thousands of palm trees. From Tinfou you will start to see the dunes of Sahara Tiguida. Once you arrive at Mhamid El Ghezlan you will climb into your JEEP 4X4, waiting to take you on an amazing adventure along the Big Dunes of Sahara Erg Chegaga Dunes. Overnight in a Berber Camp in Erg Lihoudi under the stars. You will spend this astonishing night a in Berber Camp with a traditional Moroccan dinner while enjoying Berber Gnawa Music.

Wake up early in the morning to climb sand dunes for an experience of a lifetime in the magical desert atmosphere to watch the sunrise over the Sahara desert. Then back to the camp to have a Berber Breakfast. Afterwards you will continue on your journey to Taroudant where you will spend the night. If you arrive early in Taroudant there is an option to have local guide and visit the Medina of Taroudant. On the way you will enjoy local lunch before you arrive in Taroudant. Overnight in the Hotel / Riad in Taroudant.

There is only 70 KM between Taroudant and Agadir which allows you to have a wonderful day with less hours in the car. Once you arrive Agadir you will visit Agadir Ouflla, and optionally, the Market Souk Al Hadd. Then head to the beach to relax and have free time by the seaside. In and around Agadir it’s time to take in the beautiful vast ocean. A popular sea resort, especially for windsurfers, the town gets 340 days of sunshine a year! Explore the pretty village and markets, and relax along the southern Atlantic coastline of Morocco.

Another day by the seaside and ocean. From Agadir to Essaouira you will take the coastal route. You will pass by many Berber villages, passing banana plantations en route. Once you get Essaouira you can enjoy vast beaches, delicious Moroccan seafood and water sports. Essaouira is one of Morocco’s best beach destinations.

Have a delicious breakfast, and then depart from Essaouira around 9AM to head back to Marrakech. There is an oppotunity to stop at an argan forest to see the tree-climbing goats eating the argan trees and visit the Women's Cooperative of Argan Oil, if you fancy. Once you get to Marrakech you'll have enough time to visit the authentic city of Marrakech and visit historical sites like the Koutoubia Mosque, Saadien Tombs, Bahia Palace, the Main Square: Jemaa el-Fnaa, Majorelle Gardens, and more!
Departure to Marrakech airport following your flight departure time.

generalInfo:
This immersive 16-day journey takes you across two continents, weaving together Spain’s vibrant cities and Morocco’s imperial heartlands in a seamless exploration of history, culture, cuisine, and living traditions.

Your adventure begins in Madrid, Spain’s energetic capital, where grand boulevards, elegant plazas, and historic neighborhoods set the tone. You ease into local life with evenings spent hopping between time-honored taverns, discovering the social ritual of tapas and wine as Madrileños do. A guided walk through the historic Habsburg district reveals royal palaces, lively squares, and hidden corners that tell the story of Madrid’s imperial past.

Traveling south by high-speed rail, you arrive in Granada, where Moorish heritage and Andalusian charm converge beneath the Sierra Nevada. Here, history unfolds through the senses—from a unique scent-based exploration of the old city to the awe-inspiring Alhambra, whose palaces and gardens speak to centuries of artistic and political power. As night falls, flamenco comes alive inside a Sacromonte cave, offering an intimate glimpse into one of Spain’s most passionate art forms.

Continuing through Andalusia, you journey through olive-grove landscapes, stopping at a historic estate to learn why olive oil is Spain’s liquid gold. In Seville, architectural grandeur takes center stage: Gothic cathedrals, royal palaces, and orange-tree-filled neighborhoods reveal layers of Christian, Jewish, and Muslim influence. A hands-on market visit and cooking class deepen your connection to local culture through food.

Crossing the Strait of Gibraltar marks a powerful transition as Europe fades behind you and Africa comes into view. In Tangier, you explore winding medinas, ancient kasbahs, and vibrant neighborhoods shaped by centuries of cultural exchange. From here, a scenic road trip leads to Chefchaouen, the famed Blue Pearl of the Rif Mountains, before continuing to Fes—Morocco’s oldest imperial city and a living medieval masterpiece.

In Fes, labyrinthine streets, historic madrasas, colorful tanneries, and artisan souks immerse you in traditions that have endured for generations. You then travel onward through Meknes and Rabat, encountering monumental gates, royal mausoleums, and coastal elegance, before arriving in Casablanca to visit the breathtaking Hassan II Mosque, dramatically poised above the Atlantic.

Your journey concludes in Marrakech, where sunrise reveals desert landscapes from a hot air balloon and the city’s vibrant soul unfolds in palaces, gardens, souks, and the ever-lively Jemaa el Fna square. From rooftop cafés to hidden courtyards, Marrakech offers a fitting finale—rich, colorful, and unforgettable.

This thoughtfully paced itinerary blends iconic landmarks with intimate local experiences, offering a deep and rewarding journey through the shared histories and striking contrasts of Spain and Morocco.

dayInfo.description: Upon arrival at Madrid Airport, your private driver will be waiting for you after you have collected your luggage and exited into the arrival hall. Transfer to your hotel and take time to relax after your journey. Spain’s vibrant capital, Madrid is known for its grand boulevards, elegant plazas, and world-class art collections, including the Prado Museum. With its lively café culture, historic neighborhoods, and infectious energy, the city offers a perfect introduction to Spain’s rich heritage and contemporary life.

Welcome Dinner Spanish Style Get to know the “going out for tapas” experience as the people of Madrid live it. Get ready to stand up and drink slowly, tasting a fantastic parade of dishes and wines from various regions of Spain, which have always found their place in the melting pot that is Madrid. You will visit a place that is as old in its concept as it is rare these days (more than 80 years in operation), an old inn where you will be brought closer to the history of Madrid with large boards of wines by the glass and the tapas of the day. The guide will advise on the wines and will order more portions for you to continue discovering gastronomy. Then you will visit two hundred-year-old taverns, the first has been in the same location for more than 100 years, and the second hides in its caves the secret of why Lorca or Pablo Neruda used to visit it. At the end of the tour you will have learned the key to wines, gastronomy (some for the intrepid), enjoying anecdotes from 18th-century Madrid as you stroll through its streets.

Exploring Madrid’s Historic Heart On this privately guided walk through Madrid, you explore the Spanish capital’s most beautiful and emblematic places. The focus today is the Habsburg district, the oldest part of the city, known locally as El Madrid de los Austrias. As you wander through this historic heart of Madrid—developed during the Habsburg dynasty between 1510 and 1700—you encounter striking landmarks such as the Royal Palace (Palacio Real de Madrid), the Almudena Cathedral, and the grand Plaza Mayor. Along the way, you also slip into lesser-known streets and hidden corners, uncovering overlooked details and quiet mysteries of the old town. Your knowledgeable local guide shares engaging stories and insights that bring the city’s past and present to life. To take a break from exploring, pause for a drink at an authentic local spot recommended by your guide, soaking up Madrid’s lively atmosphere. With a deeper understanding of the city’s history and culture, the rest of the day is yours to continue discovering Madrid at your own pace—linger in a favorite plaza, explore a neighborhood café, or simply enjoy the rhythm of local life.

High-Speed Train to Granada At the appointed time, your private driver meets you at your hotel and transfers you comfortably to Madrid’s Puerta de Atocha train station. From here, you board the high-speed train bound for Granada, enjoying a smooth and scenic journey of approximately 3.5 hours through the Spanish countryside. Upon arrival at Granada’s train station, your private driver is waiting to greet you and escort you directly to your hotel. Sit back and relax as you are introduced to Granada, a city where Andalusian charm, Moorish heritage, and the dramatic backdrop of the Sierra Nevada come together, setting the stage for the experiences to come.

You follow a unique route that immerses you in an authentic, sensory experience, transporting you through different eras of Granada’s history using carefully curated scents connected to each time and place. As you move through the city, aromas become a guide, awakening memories and emotions tied to Granada’s rich past. Through these scents, you discover emblematic sites such as El Bañuelo, a hammam dating back to the Zirid period, the majestic Granada Cathedral, built in the 16th century on the site of a former mosque, and the colorful Alcaicería—once a Moorish silk market and now a lively maze of Andalusian treats, crafts, and souvenirs. A Sensory Walk Through Historic Granada When the experience ends, you take away more than memories. A small box of the fragrances you’ve encountered allows you to revisit this evocative journey and relive the essence of Granada long after your stay.

Inside Granada’s Alhambra Granada stands as the final stronghold of Al-Andalus, the last Muslim kingdom in Spain, and its layered history unfolds before you as you explore the city’s most iconic landmark: the Alhambra. Rising above Granada, this remarkable complex draws visitors from around the world and remains a powerful symbol of the city’s Moorish past. You stroll through its grand halls and courtyards, where intricate details and quiet spaces evoke centuries of history, then wander the Generalife Gardens. Filled with colorful flowers, flowing fountains, and shaded walkways, the gardens offer sweeping panoramic views over the city below. Perched atop a hill overlooking Granada, the Alhambra traces its origins to the 9th century and was later transformed in the 14th century by the Nasrid dynasty into a magnificent Moorish palace. After the Christian Reconquest in 1492, it became the royal court of Ferdinand and Isabella. Today, as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, it stands as one of Spain’s most extraordinary cultural treasures. In the evening, you head to the Sacromonte neighborhood, where flamenco comes to life in one of its most authentic settings—a natural cave carved into the hillside. Andalusia, the birthplace of flamenco, sets the stage for this deeply expressive art form, and you gain insight into its origins, influences, and rise to global recognition.

Visit to an Olive Oil Estate, Spain's Liquid Gold. At the appointed time, your private driver meets you at your hotel in Granada, and you set off on a comfortable transfer toward Seville, traveling through the heart of the Andalusian countryside. Along the way, you stop at a family-run olive oil estate to discover one of Spain’s most celebrated exports. Here, you gain firsthand insight into the olive oil production process during an exclusive visit to the estate. Steeped in history, this property traces its legacy back to the 17th century, when Hernando Colón, the son of Christopher Columbus, began exporting olive oil from this very land to the New World. You explore the estate’s historic production center, viewing impressive 16th-century olive oil presses that tell the story of centuries-old traditions. You then visit the modern facilities, where contemporary techniques are used to produce the high-quality olive oils still exported today. The experience concludes with a tasting of the estate’s oils, giving you the opportunity to savor their distinct flavors and put your newly gained knowledge to the test before continuing on to Seville. Back in Seville, you set out on a guided walk through the city’s historic center, discovering some of its most celebrated landmarks. You visit the Seville Cathedral, a vast 15th-century Roman Catholic church that houses the tomb of Christopher Columbus. A UNESCO World Heritage Site and the largest Gothic cathedral in the world, it stands as an awe-inspiring symbol of Seville’s wealth and devotion. Nearby, you admire La Giralda, the cathedral’s iconic bell tower, rising above the city skyline. From here, you continue into the Santa Cruz neighborhood, Seville’s former Jewish Quarter. As you wander its narrow streets and sun-dappled squares lined with orange trees, you experience one of the city’s most charming and well-preserved areas. With its lively cafés and traditional tapas bars, it’s an ideal place to pause, sample small plates, and enjoy a glass of local wine. You also explore the Alcázar of Seville, a magnificent palace complex and UNESCO World Heritage Site. With its ornate rooms and lush gardens, the Alcázar beautifully reflects the harmonious blend of Christian and Muslim influences that has shaped Seville’s history.

Traditional Andalusian Market Visit & Cooking Class If you’re hungry to make a deep, cultural connection, something intangible to take home and cherish long after your vacation is over, and explore Spanish cuisine, this is for you! You will learn from our passionate chef about not only Spanish food, but the culture as well. You will start this morning by touring a local market where we source the ingredients for your cooking class. After that informative visit, you put on your kitchen apron and learn how to cook some of the most representative local dishes, along with the crown jewel, our stunning paella. During lunch, your host shares stories about each of the dishes to help illustrate various aspects of Andalusian culture: a bit of history, a touch of sociology, tongue-in-cheek humor, and quite a bit of gastronomy. Free Time in Sevilla or Optional Half-day Excursion to Córdoba Córdoba is yet another romantic city in the Andalusia region, filled with historic Mudéjar architecture. This historically rich city is home to some of the country's most important monuments, such as the Mosque Cathedral and the Alcázar de Los Reyes Cristianos. Also very important is the Roman Bridge, with the Calahorra, a defensive tower of Arab origin located at one of its ends. It can be visited and from the top you can enjoy a beautiful view of the Roman Bridge with the Puerta del Puente and the Mosque-Cathedral in the background. You can also visit the city's incredible Jewish quarter and synagogue, tour a traditional souk market and follow the medieval walls. Transportation by train

At the appointed time, your private driver meets you at your hotel in Seville and transfers you south to the port of Tarifa, Spain’s southernmost point. From here, you board the ferry and cross the Strait of Gibraltar, a legendary waterway that separates Europe from Africa and connects the Mediterranean Sea with the Atlantic Ocean. During the short but scenic crossing, you may glimpse both continents at once—a powerful moment marking your transition between cultures. Upon arrival at the port of Tangier, you step into Morocco’s northern gateway. Long shaped by Phoenician, Roman, Arab, and European influences, Tangier has served for centuries as a crossroads between worlds. Your private driver meets you at the port and escorts you to your hotel, offering a first glimpse of the city’s vibrant streets, coastal views, and distinctive blend of African, Arab, and Mediterranean character as you begin the next chapter of your journey. In afternoon, Today, you experience Tangier on its own terms, exploring the city’s rich local culture alongside a knowledgeable guide. You wander through the historic Kasbah and Medina, where winding streets and layered histories reveal the soul of the city. You visit the 17th-century Sultan’s Palace, now a museum displaying Roman remains, traditional crafts, and artifacts that reflect Morocco’s deep-rooted heritage. Continuing into the Medina, you meander through bustling alleyways, passing communal bread ovens, the weavers’ quarter, and small local eateries that offer a glimpse into everyday life. By the end of the walk, Tangier feels more familiar, leaving you with lasting impressions of its people, traditions, and timeless charact

Road Trip to Fes via Chefchaouen, "The Blue Pearl". Today you set off on a scenic road trip toward Fes, with a memorable stop in Chefchaouen, famously known as “the Blue Pearl.” As you travel beneath the rugged peaks of the Rif Mountains, the landscape gradually shifts before revealing one of Morocco’s most picturesque towns. Perched in the mountains and washed in shades of blue, Chefchaouen feels like a world of its own. Founded in 1471 as a fortified settlement, the town blends spiritual significance with a relaxed, artistic atmosphere. With your local guide, you explore the old medina, where blue-painted streets, red-tiled roofs, and narrow lanes lead to the lively Plaza Uta el-Hammam and its restored kasbah. You wander through nearby souks, admire the Grand Mosque from the outside, and visit the kasbah’s gardens and historic spaces. For sweeping views over the blue city, you step just beyond the old walls and pass through historic gates toward a scenic viewpoint near Hotel Atlas. After your visit, you continue your journey through the Moroccan countryside, arriving in Fes later in the day, ready to explore one of the country’s most storied imperial cities.

Discovering Fes with a Local Guide Today, you explore Fes, the oldest of Morocco’s imperial cities and one of its most fascinating, accompanied by a private local guide who brings its history and traditions to life. Often described as a living museum, Fes feels largely untouched by time, offering an immersive glimpse into centuries-old daily life. You step into the UNESCO-listed medina, the most complete of its kind in the Arab world, where narrow alleys and ancient walls create a maze of discovery. As you wander, you see highlights such as the ruins of the Merinid tombs, the beautifully preserved Bou Inania and Attarine madrasas from the 14th century, the revered Al Quaraouiyine Mosque—one of the oldest centers of Islamic learning—and the ornate Nejjarine Fountain. You pause for lunch at a traditional Moroccan restaurant before continuing your exploration. The afternoon reveals the striking blue-and-green gate of Bab Boujeloud, the bustling medieval tanneries, and views of the Royal Palace gates. You then dive into the lively souks, where artisans craft and sell jewelry, leather goods, copperware, and pottery, offering a vivid look at the skills and trades that have shaped Fes for generations. In the afternoon, a Moroccan traditional cooking class You head to your cooking class, which begins with a visit to a nearby souk to shop for produce — just as the locals do. As you prepare a traditional four-course meal, complete with fragrant spices, vibrant saffron, and the ubiquitous preserved lemon, you'll learn about traditional Moroccan cooking methods and will hopefully create amazing memories. At the end of class, sit down to enjoy your delicious dishes, which you can recreate once you're home from your trip.

Road Trip to Rabat via Meknes. Today, you set off for the nearby city of Meknes, Morocco’s third imperial city, often called the “Versailles of Morocco.” With your guide, you explore its monumental gates, including Bab El Khamis and the impressive Bab El Mansour, considered one of the most beautiful gates in the country. You also visit the Mausoleum of Moulay Ismail, gaining insight into the legacy of the sultan who shaped much of the city’s grandeur. After your visit to Meknes, you continue onward to Rabat. Morocco’s capital since 1956 and a UNESCO World Heritage Site, Rabat offers a blend of historic landmarks and modern elegance. During a panoramic visit of the administrative capital, you see highlights such as the Royal Palace, the Mausoleum of Mohammed V, and the iconic Hassan Tower—the minaret of an unfinished mosque begun by the Almohad ruler Yaacoub al-Mansour.

Private Transfer Rabat to Casablanca You depart Rabat by private transfer and travel along the Atlantic coast to Casablanca, Morocco’s largest city and economic hub. Upon arrival, you visit the Hassan II Mosque, the city’s most iconic landmark and an unmissable highlight. Dramatically set on the edge of the Atlantic Ocean, this vast complex includes a museum, traditional baths, a Quranic school, a library, and an immense prayer hall supported by 78 granite and marble pillars. Completed in 1993, the mosque is the largest in Morocco and the second-largest in the world. Its soaring minaret rises 650 feet (200 meters), making it the tallest minaret on the planet. As you approach, you admire the striking exterior and oceanfront setting before stepping inside—one of the rare mosques in Morocco open to non-Muslims. Your guide helps you appreciate the intricate craftsmanship, from shimmering mosaic tiles and carved stone to marble columns, wooden details, and soaring, ornamented ceilings. Emerald-green roof tiles crown the structure, and as evening approaches, the mosque glows warmly against the Atlantic, its lights reflecting off the rolling waves. Created by master artisans from across Morocco, the Hassan II Mosque stands as a breathtaking testament to the country’s architectural and artistic heritage.

Coastal Road trip to Marrakech via El Jadida Today, you leave Casablanca—Morocco’s commercial center—and travel south along the Atlantic coast toward Essaouira, enjoying sweeping ocean views along the way. En route, you stop in El Jadida, formerly known as Mazagan, a fortified city founded by the Portuguese in the early 16th century and later reclaimed by Sultan Mohammed ben Abdallah in 1769. Now a UNESCO World Heritage Site, El Jadida is celebrated for its well-preserved Renaissance-era design. You explore its historic ramparts, bastions, and atmospheric cistern, gaining insight into the city’s layered past and strategic importance along the coast. In the afternoon, you continue your journey inland toward Marrakech, where the pace quickens and a new chapter of your Moroccan adventure begins.

Getting to know Marrakech You rise early for an unforgettable hot air balloon flight over the desert outside Marrakech. As the sun lifts over the horizon, you float quietly above the landscape, taking in pastel skies, soft morning light, and sweeping views—a peaceful contrast to the city’s usual energy below. Later, you explore Marrakech, Morocco’s vibrant “Red City,” with a local guide. You wander through the historic center, visiting highlights such as the elegant Bahia Palace, where lush courtyards, gardens, and intricate woodwork showcase late 19th-century Moroccan craftsmanship. You also admire the Koutoubia Mosque and its gardens from the outside, its iconic minaret dominating the skyline. Passing through one of the medina’s historic gates, you dive into the maze of souks and hidden fondouks, where artisans sell spices, leather goods, dyed textiles, and traditional crafts. Your walk leads to Jemaa el Fna Square, the city’s lively heart. As evening falls, food stalls sizzle, musicians and performers gather, and the square comes alive. You can sample local street food or relax at a rooftop café and watch the spectacle unfold below. The rest of the time is yours to enjoy Marrakech at your own pace, with the option to visit the serene Majorelle Garden—created by Jacques Majorelle and later restored by Yves Saint Laurent—or spend more time soaking up the city’s unique atmosphere.
Today it is time to say goodbye to Morrocco. You have a private transfer to the airport.

generalInfo:
Prepare to be swept away on an extraordinary 14-day expedition that traverses the captivating tapestry of Morocco’s diverse and exciting destinations. From the bustling metropolis of Casablanca to the coastal charm of Essaouira, each stop on this journey promises a unique experience that unveils the heart and soul of this remarkable country. Journey onward to the vibrant markets and cultural richness of Marrakech, then venture into the desert in Zagora, where golden sands meet the horizon. Coastal Agadir beckons with its pristine beaches and the charming town of Essaouira captivates with its historic medina and artistic soul. Join us as we embark on this 14-day exploration of Casablanca, Rabat, Meknes, Volubilis, Chefchaouen, Fes, Marrakech, Zagora, Agadir, and Essaouira – a transformative journey that promises to etch Morocco’s beauty into your heart forever.

Why You’ll Love This Tour
This 14-day adventure offers a remarkable blend of experiences, from coastal Essaouira to the Saharan landscapes of Zagora, ensuring that every day brings a new and breathtaking backdrop to explore.
Recharge at hand-picked 4-star hotels .
Uncover the rich history of Morocco as you explore ancient ruins like Volubilis, discover the grandeur of imperial cities, and roam through historic medinas that have stood the test of time.
Relax and enjoy the journey with seamless travel arrangements, carefully chosen accommodations, and expert guides who will ensure you get the most out of each destination without the stress of planning.
Indulge in the flavors of Moroccan cuisine, from aromatic tagines to delectable pastries.
Venture into the Sahara in Zagora, where you can experience the magic of the desert dunes, perhaps even with a camel ride at sunset, creating unforgettable memories against the backdrop of endless sand.
No night drives, so you can rest comfortably. However, some long drives are required to cover all these incredible experiences.

dayInfo.description: Welcome to Morocco! Keep your eyes peeled at Casablanca Airport for the sign for your transfer to the hotel. Freshen up and meet in the lobby around 7:00pm for an informal meeting with your guide and other tour members. Afterwards you have free time to start exploring vibrant Casablanca or go out for an optional group dinner and mingle with fellow travellers.

Embark on a captivating Casablanca journey with a guided tour of the monumental Hassan II Mosque, a true marvel and the largest in all of Africa. This architectural masterpiece will leave you in awe of its intricate details and grandeur. Continuing your adventure, the tour will lead you to the remarkable United Nations Square, a vibrant hub that resonates with the cosmopolitan essence of the city. As you move on, immerse yourself in the elegance of the Anfa Residential Quarter, where modernity meets sophistication in the heart of Casablanca. Gathering unforgettable memories, you’ll then board a comfortable bus and follow the enchanting coastline towards Rabat, the captivating capital of Morocco. Nestled within a landscape bathed in warm amber hues, Rabat is a harmonious blend of age-old history and contemporary Moroccan vibrancy. The guided walking expedition through this imperial city will gradually unveil its beauty, taking you to pivotal sites including the Royal Palace and Chellah Ruins. Your journey continues as you make your way to Meknes, a city steeped in its own history and charm.

Today promises an enriching exploration as we delve into the treasures of Meknes, a city with a storied past and vibrant present. Our journey begins with visits to the awe-inspiring Bab Mansour, a monumental gate that stands as a testament to Meknes’ architectural prowess and historical significance. As we wander through its majestic archways, we’ll be transported back in time, connecting with the city’s illustrious heritage. Continuing our expedition, we’ll venture to the ancient Berber ruins of Volubilis, where echoes of centuries past reverberate through the timeworn stones. Our journey takes us further to the charming Moulay Driss Zarhoun, a captivating enclave that holds the esteemed title of Morocco’s cultural capital. Guided by our knowledgeable companion, we’ll unravel the threads of the region’s remarkable history and its profound influence on Moroccan culture. As the afternoon sun paints the sky with hues of gold, we’ll make our way to Chefchaouen, fondly known as the Blue City.

Immerse yourself completely in the mesmerizing tapestry of Chefchaouen, often referred to as the Blue City, as we dedicate the day to its enchanting allure. Grab your cameras and embark on an adventure through the narrow, winding streets of this picturesque blue-washed mountain village. Don’t miss the chance to soak in the vibrant energy of Outa el-Hammam Square, a hub of activity where local life unfolds against the backdrop of the blue cityscape. Venture further to experience the natural wonders that surround Chefchaouen. A visit to the mesmerizing Ras el-Maa waterfall promises a refreshing and serene encounter with nature’s beauty. The cascading waters and lush surroundings provide a perfect contrast to the vibrant blue of the city. For a panoramic view that will leave you speechless, make your way to the Spanish Mosque. As the day progresses, we’ll embark on a scenic drive that takes us to the cultural heart of Morocco – Fes. This second largest city in the country beckons with its rich history and a tapestry of experiences waiting to be unravelled.

Prepare to lace up your walking shoes and step into a captivating cultural odyssey through the imperial city of Fes. Let the allure of this historical gem unfold as you embark on an immersive journey, guided by the insights of a local expert. Our intensive tour will sweep you through the highlights, revealing the city’s layered past and vibrant present. The adventure kicks off at the majestic Bab Bouloud Gate, a gateway to the Royal Palace that stands as a symbol of Fes’ regal heritage. The Mausoleum of Moulay Idriss, a sacred site of pilgrimage, offers a glimpse into the spiritual heart of the city. Our exploration takes us to Najjarine Square, a lively hub where history and contemporary life converge. As we journey on, the Mellah, Fes’ historic Jewish Quarter, adds yet another layer to the city’s cultural tapestry. Delve into the world of traditional pottery, witnessing skilled artisans at work and perhaps even trying your hand at the craft.

As the morning sun bathes the landscape in a warm glow, we’ll set forth on our journey to the captivating city of Marrakech. This city serves as a confluence where the vibrant Arab urban culture intersects with the rugged authenticity of Berber life from the desert and mountain villages. As we step into the heart of Marrakech, get ready to don your haggling hats and embrace the vibrant energy of Djemaa el-Fna Square. As the evening draws near, Djemaa el-Fna transforms into a twilight wonderland, where the vibrant tapestry of Marrakech’s diverse cultures and traditions takes center stage. Embrace the mayhem and let the magic of this square captivate your senses.

Indulge in a delectable breakfast to kickstart a day of exploration and enchantment. Your journey through the vibrant tapestry of Marrakech begins by unveiling the city’s key sites, each a treasure trove of history and culture waiting to be discovered. Marvel at the magnificence of the Koutoubia Mosque, venture onward to the Saadian Tombs, and Step into the opulent world of the Bahia Palace, where intricate architecture and lush gardens create a haven of tranquility amidst the city’s hustle and bustle. At the Dar Si Said Museum, you’ll be immersed in the artistic heritage of Marrakech, as intricate woodwork, vibrant textiles, and exquisite artifacts tell the story of the city’s craftsmanship and creativity. As you move through these sites, the layers of Marrakech’s history and culture will unfurl before you, offering a deeper understanding of the city’s rich tapestry.

Following a satisfying breakfast, embark on a scenic journey to Ouarzazate, a place where the mesmerizing landscapes of Morocco’s heartland unfold. Our destination is the renowned Berber Village of Ait Ben Haddou, a site that beckons with its timeless charm and cultural significance. Prepare to be enchanted by the cinematic allure of Ait Ben Haddou, as you step into a world that has graced the silver screen in numerous Hollywood productions. As our journey continues, we’ll take a moment to immerse ourselves in the warmth of Berber hospitality. A stop at a local Berber house offers the opportunity to connect with the heart of Morocco’s cultural heritage.

Your venture into the endless expanse of the Sahara Desert is an adventure that promises to etch unforgettable memories. Follow the path that winds along the enchanting Draa Valley, a journey that unveils the subtle transition from the fertile greenery to the vast desert. The journey pauses at a serene oasis, offering a haven of shade and tranquility. Here, indulge in a locally prepared lunch that reflects the flavors of the land, a moment of nourishment amidst the desert’s grandeur. Zagora, situated at the edge of the Sahara, serves as the gateway to your desert odyssey. Here, the landscape transforms, and you’ll transition to a 4×4 jeep safari, a vehicle designed to navigate the ever-shifting sands with grace and precision. As you journey deeper into the Sahara, the golden dunes of M’hamid beckon.

As the Saharan sun paints the sky with hues of gold, awaken to a moment that seems to transcend time itself. Embark on an adventure that truly embodies the spirit of the desert. Mount your camel, a trusty companion that has traversed these sands for generations, and set out across the vast Sahara. The journey to our next camp in Zagora is a passage through both space and time. Feel the gentle swaying of your camel beneath you as you traverse the golden dunes, a symphony of grains and light unfolding before your eyes. Arriving at your destination, a local house nestled in the heart of the desert, you’ll share a meal that not only nourishes your body but also connects you to the essence of the land and its people.

Bid farewell to the desert’s timeless embrace as you open your arms to the boundless expanse of the ocean. The transition from the mesmerizing Sahara sands to the sandy shores of Agadir marks a shift from one enchanting landscape to another. Stroll through the picturesque village, its quaint streets lined with treasures waiting to be discovered. As you explore, you’ll find moments of reprieve along the southern Atlantic coastline.

Rejoin your fellow travelers on the coach and embark on a picturesque drive that traces the captivating curves of the ocean coast, weaving through verdant banana plantations that add a touch of vibrant green to the scenery. This journey leads us to the enchanting destination of Essaouira, a crown jewel among Morocco’s sea-side getaways. Essaouira’s allure is multifaceted, offering a delightful range of experiences that cater to every traveler’s preferences.

Time to bid farewell to the ocean as you embark on a scenic drive to Marrakech through Argan trees. If you’re lucky, you may meet goats climbing the trees! Late in the afternoon you will reach the fascinating city of Marrakech. It is where the Arab city culture meets the Berber culture of the desert and mountain villages. Here, the sub-Saharan traders would trade their wares with European merchants, who would then bring them to Europe. Wear your haggling hats as you discover Djemaa el-Fna Square and brace for the mayhem! Marking the entrance to the huge bazaar, the area is packed with story tellers, snake charmers, acrobats, musicians and folk dancers.
Have your final breakfast on us and start bidding farewells to your travel mates before checking out of the hotel (11:00). Time to start counting days for your next adventure with us!

generalInfo:
This specialist mammal watching tour focuses on the some wonderful but often elusive desert wildlife (particularly mammals) of the remote Western Sahara. There is a special focus on the rare and iconic nocturnal mammals of this part of the world and so there are some very long (but productive and rewarding) nights of spotlighting throughout the trip.

Introduction:
On this rare wildlife tour some of our targeted species are among the rarest and most elusive nocturnal creatures in the world (as well as being some of the most sought after species of mammal watchers worldwide). Species such as African golden wolf, Fennec & Ruppell’s Foxes, African wild cat, Sand Cat, Saharan Striped Polecat & Desert Hedgehog are all possible on this tour and we have a very good success rate with many of these species including the two top priority animals which are fennec foxes and sand cats.

The tour will involve some stunning desert camping and after dark the beautiful and spectacular starry skies are among some of the best in the world. All in all this tour is a great overview of the Western Sahara’s fascinating and unique wildlife, much of which is very difficult to see elsewhere.

We are specialists in tailoring wildlife watching all over the world and we have a great range of wildlife safaris of Africa including Morocco and Western Sahara. The Western Sahara is huge country with some of the most remote and isolated wilderness anywhere in the world and is home to some of the most specialised species in the world.

It is hard not to be mesmerised by the expanse of sand and wilderness of the Sahara and it is easy to think that the whole area is devoid of life, however on closer inspection there are many species of birds and reptiles which live on the dunes and gravel pans during the day and then after dark when the temperatures drop the landscape comes alive with jerboas, gerbils and their predators which include various foxes, mustelids and of course the tiny sand cat.

We are specialists at rare mammal watching tours all over the world and can tailor tours to any specifictions. Whether you are interested in desert mammals of the Western Sahara or trying to see the critically endangered Javan Rhino or look for Giant Pandas in China we have the options for you, as well as many other safari options.

Group Tour Departure: 12th March - 19th March 2024

Price Includes:

Everything mentioned in the itinerary is included. Including three meals per day (breakfast, lunch and dinner) where mentioned, in some locations lunch and dinner are not included (please refer to the itinerary), such as in Dakhla. We have our own private air conditioned 4x4 vehicles with an excellent driver for all transfers and game drives and spotlighting. Where possible we use two brilliant guides; first a professional zoologist (when available - zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) who will escort you on all your excursions and we also have very knowledgeable English speaking local naturalist guides who have decades of experience working and guiding through Western Sahara. Your naturalist escort is an expert in wildlife biology and behaviour and will be able to help you identify the different species as well as interpret you what behaviours you are seeing. The local guides have spent years searching out the best wildlife watching locations and have an unrivalled knowledge where we are going to visit. Where needed we further employ local guides at specific locations where their intimate knowledge of individual reserves and parks is invaluable in finding our targeted species. We also include all vehicle safaris, guided walks, park entrance fees and sightseeing entrance fees. Whilst the trip involves a lot of camps, for the camping we will provide all of the camping equipment the only thing you will need to bring is your sleeping bag. We include more time spent in the field searching for wildlife per day than any other tour operator around; only if you request to have a rest day will we not arrange a safari into the Western Saharan wilderness, night safaris are available in some locations (subject to the local conditions on that day). You will have to speak to your guide on arrival there and book places on these (this is not included). A comprehensive species list (which states the relative chances of seeing animals based on past tours) is included in the pre-departure pack. There is also a reference book library available for your use throughout the trip as well as some documentaries on the wildlife that you are likely to see which are available to watch throughout the tour (subject to availability of a zoologist guide - zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us).

Seasons:

We plan this tour in February, however it could be done in most times of year. The reason for February is temperature as it is cooler in the winter and so the wildlife is more active for longer than in the hotter times of year. Also there is more night time hours and as most of the wildlife on the trip is nocturnal, that factor helps us also.

Why Choose this Tour:

• All of our wildlife watching holidays are guided by an experienced naturalist guides as well as local drivers and also scientists or researchers where possible, this not only gives you numerous sets of trained eyes to find the animals but also gives you the chance to understand the behaviours and habits of the wildlife you’re watching.
• Our zoologist (where available - if you wish to have a zoologist please contact us and we can check availability - not all tours include a zoologist) that escorts tours (where available) has a great wealth of knowledge.
• We can also offer further wildlife watching activities if they present themselves whilst on the trip. For example our local guides keep their ears to the ground and have many contacts and if and when a new location of animal is known and reliably seen we can head there to experience it. We do our best to include as many wildlife activities as possible in all of our itineraries.
• Depending on budget and interest we have a range of different accommodation packages to offer, from luxury top end lodges, national park safari lodges and mobile-camps which often offer unbelievable wildlife watching deep inside national parks as well as camping. We can also arrange mobile camping safaris of Botswana is very popular and all of your camping gear will be provided.
• Spend all the daylight hours searching for wildlife and visiting various natural wonders and stunning landscapes.
• All the above reasons give this, our Western Sahara wildlife safaris a great success rate of seeing the best wildlife around here. We have an unrivalled network of experts and guides throughout Southern Africa so that we can try and find and observe some of the rarer and more elusive species. We have great itineraries and expertise in all African countries (such as Namibia, Gabon, Ethiopia, Madagascar, South Africa, Tanzania, Botswana, Kenya, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Malawi, Uganda, Rwanda and Mozambique) and can arrange trips to find some of the rarer species such as mandrills, aardvarks, gelada baboons aardwolves, brown hyenas and black-footed cats among other species. Please inform us if you wish to receive more information about any of these locations and booking a safari.
• Unlike many tour operators we are willing to run this tour for a single person (on request).

Locations:

This tour visits two general locations within Western Sahara, however they are best kept relatively secret as they are unprotected and so we do not want to highlight the presence of wildlife in these areas and potentially open the area up to poaching.

Fitness Level:

The vast majority of wildlife watching is all done from a vehicle and whilst there is some walking, most of the walking is over flat terrain. This doesn't require any special fitness level. The biggest consideration is the heat, it is very hot in the wilderness of Western Sahara during the day.

Equipment:

When you book onto the tour we will send you a comprehensive pre-departure pack which will include a full packing list of recommended equipment; the equipment list will vary from tour to tour and from location to location so it is best to contact us or wait until you receive the pre-departure pack after booking.

Minimum Age: 15 Years Old

dayInfo.description: Dakhla - Arrival & Travelling Most flights in the Western Sahara arrive in Dakhla via Casablanca and arrive early in the morning where we will be met by our local guide and transferred to a comfortable tourist hotel nearby. (no meals included today)

Dakhla - Travelling This is our last full day in the Western Sahara and once we leave the house we will make our way back to Dakhla. In the evening once we arrive we will enjoy a relaxing final dinner and will recall the great selection of encounters with exciting species. (breakfast and lunch included today)
Home After breakfast you will be transferred to the airport in time to catch your return flight home. (breakfast included today).

tourName: 12-Day Best of Spain and Morocco Itinerary
placesVisited: Madrid, Seville, Zahara de la Sierra, Ronda, Granada, Alhambra, Andalusia, Albaicin, Marrakesh, High Atlas Mountains, Berber villages
generalInfo: While many people travel to Spain and Morocco for their impressive monuments, on this 12-day tour you will experience the vibrant culture of these two soulful countries. Both will whisk you away on a blanket of enchantment as they reveal the legacies of history and the poignancy of today. With six days in each country, this best-of luxury tour is a celebration of the styles and the surreal atmospheres of Spain and Morocco, which features private guides and handpicked accommodation throughout Madrid, Seville, Granada, Marrakesh and the High Atlas.

dayInfo.title: Madrid – A Culinary Introduction to a Luxury Tour
dayInfo.description: Upon your arrival in Madrid, as you wander the charming and charismatic streets, it will be hard to believe that you are in a capital city. Strangers greet each other, small establishments know their guests by name, and the sounds of chatter and clinking glasses far outweigh any traffic. Parts of the Spanish capital feel like a village, as their gregarious makeup is quick to make an impression on visitors. However, these streets also have the vibrant advantages of a city. Aromas of garlic and olive oil emanate from the taverns, great menus of wine are available by the glass, and dishes are created by the country’s top chefs. Your driver will meet you at the airport and escort you to your Central Madrid hotel that blends vintage design with contemporary luxury. After you settle into your hotel, you will discover that the city is a culinary paradise. The classic way to discover it all is on a tapas crawl, a Madrileno ritual that isn’t just about what you eat and drink. As you join the locals on these old narrow streets, you will get an immediate sense of what Madrid is all about, from the architecture to the atmosphere. Led by a local guide, the tapas crawl allows for a relaxed introduction to the city. End your night with a casual stroll to your centrally located hotel, which is accessible on foot, while also providing a peaceful setting for returning to after the evening of tapas and wine.

dayInfo.title: Madrid – The Spanish Masters and the Opulence of Empire
dayInfo.description: Madrid is a city with many layers as it is a capital that grew rich in the time of the Spanish Empire that evolved over the centuries. Begin your day by standing on the baroque Plaza Mayor where you will admire the elegant arcades. Then, wander past colorful cafes to stop for chocolate and churros in an iconic early 20th-century establishment. Afterward, you will discover the legacy of the early Habsburg monarchs as the oldest part of town is marked by palatial townhouses and plazas where you can watch the world go by. Your morning will conclude at the Royal Palace, an enormous structure of marble and mahogany with gilded stucco and crystal chandeliers. While the king’s reception rooms are impressive, the guide will also take you to places that few visitors know about, such as one of the 3000 ornamental rooms that include a royal pharmacy and a library that glistens with pride. After lunch on a plaza, you will spend the late afternoon on a short tour of the Prado, the iconic home of the Spanish masters. Perhaps only Paris’s Louvre can rival the Prado for its collection of European art where the works of Velazquez and Goya are complemented by Rubens, Titian, and the names that forever changed art through the middle centuries. The evening will be at your leisure and your guide can recommend some excellent restaurants close to the hotel.

dayInfo.title: Seville – Colorful Streets and Old-World Icons
dayInfo.description: The next morning, you will say goodbye to Madrid and take the high-speed train from the city center to Seville’s city center. Arrive just around the corner from your hotel, which is a refurbished 18th-century palace that pays homage to the historical district it dominates. Elegant and old-world while also being fresh and contemporary, the hotel will feel just like the city it graces. Enjoy lunch at the hotel’s excellent restaurant then set off to discover Seville’s great monuments. You can begin at the towering cathedral, where Columbus is buried and the Gothic excess is greater than anywhere on the planet. Then, visit the Alcazar Palace, a journey through Moorish design mingling with Mudejar craft and Christian regality. Next wander through Santa Cruz, a Jewish quarter filled with vintage stores and ornamental history. Seville has a vast historical area and this tour of the major three sights will be just an introduction. Tonight, you will have a full evening to explore at leisure.

dayInfo.title: Seville – Getting Lost in the City and an Evening of Traditional Flamenco
dayInfo.description: The next day, as you gaze across the cityscape from your hotel room, you will notice how the spires dominate the skyline. As you get lost in the city on your guided tour, every corner will bring something new and surprising to your attention. Explore the aristocratic residence of Casa de Pilatos, a brilliant mix of architectural styles that’s been perfectly preserved. Afterward, discover Roman mosaics and ruins that paint an older history of the city. Then, take a stroll through a marketplace of color and noise, where castanets and fans spill from the stalls. You may want to spend an hour or two in Museo Arqueologico, or visit a sixth floor bar in the world’s largest wooden building. There are many corners to turn with your guide and the classic activity in Seville is to just go with the flow as you turn down the streets at random and embrace the enigmatic feeling of this old Andalusian city. In the evening, you will sit transfixed as you watch the emotion on a singer’s face while a mournful guitar music floats around the room and a dress twirls in musical harmony. Tonight, you will enjoy a flamenco performance at a venue within the Andalusian flamenco triangle, which is where the art form originates and the performances are as authentic as any in the country. Dinner will be included with the performance and later you may want to take a stroll since the streets will be full of energy late into the night.

dayInfo.title: Granada – Discovering the Moorish Pueblos Blancos
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will take time to admire the whitewashed villages that cling to the hills in Andalusia, creating a picture-perfect image as they stand out against the landscape. Nothing ever seems to have changed in these villages and they all have the same feeling: footsteps echo onto the cobbles, the narrow streets retain a euphonic quality, and there’s an artistic centerpiece rising proudly. Today you will travel across Andalusia to Granada, as you follow the route of the pueblos blancos and take time to stop in at least two of the villages. Zahara de la Sierra and Ronda are ideal as they have contrasts that will be difficult to see elsewhere. The journey is relatively short, yet it will take up the full day as you escape into these charming vestiges of the past. It’s not just the villages but also the landscapes that will make Andalusia special for you, as there will be dozens of viewpoints and a sense of solitude that comes as a surprise to many. During your time in Granada, you will stay in a historical building, a formerly a 19th-century mansion in the heart of the old city. It remains full of glistening treasures, featuring an intricacy of design so synonymous with the city. The evening will be at your leisure, and there are many good restaurants with a view of the illuminated Alhambra.

dayInfo.title: Granada – The Untrammeled Artistry of the Alhambra and Other Granada Highlights
dayInfo.description: Today, you will discover that few cultural experiences can rival your first impression of the Alhambra. An exquisite showpiece of the tremendous pre-medieval civilization, it’s a sophisticated symbol of grandeur that whispers over 1300 years of history. Decadent porticos line a courtyard of serenity and a forest of pillars stands over a carpet of marble. Some walls are deliberately left plain, which allows intricate murals and calligraphy to shine without competition. Surreal and sublime, this is a building that proves how much artistry existed before the Western world flourished culturally. However, it’s not just one building but a whole complex that incorporates courtyards, gardens, fortified palaces, and the residences of the Nasrid kings. After a full morning at the Alhambra, the afternoon will be at your leisure to discover this historic city. In the evening, a local guide with insider knowledge will take you on a walking tour of Albaicin, the old Moorish quarter that is packed with energy and style.

dayInfo.title: Marrakesh – First Impressions of Morocco
dayInfo.description: In the morning, it’s adios to Spain as you will be transferred to Malaga for a flight to Casablanca, where your VIP welcome will include assistance through customs and immigration. During your drive to Marrakesh from the airport, you will have the whole afternoon to stop in a number of places. Have lunch at Rick’s Cafe Casablanca, the restaurant from the classic film, Casablanca. After lunch, gaze up at the decoration of Hassan II Mosque and appreciate the soothing silence that exists in the large and lavishly adorned prayer halls. You will have the option to take a slight detour along a deserted coastline or head straight to Marrakesh, where Djemaa El-Fna is the redolent introduction to what this great city is all about.

dayInfo.title: Marrakesh – Souks, Spices and the Soul of the Past
dayInfo.description: Marrakesh has always enchanted visitors, from the old camel caravans to the travel cognoscenti that arrived in the 50s and 60s. The old town is vast and packed, a carpet of colorful chaos that can be baffling at first glance. Most alleys are barely wide enough for the donkeys that still plod through, and they jut off at impossible angles that may discombobulate you. Spices float through these alleyways, rose petals float in the trickle of city fountains, and shards of light reflect pink against the walls. This is a city with heart and soul that blends Berber life, Islamic style, contemporary influence and a proud determination to stay unique. As you begin your exploration, your private guide will provide you with insider knowledge that will always be valuable in such a labyrinth of contrasting yet complementary streets. Monuments come from across the centuries, such as the 19th-century Mnebhi Palace and the delicate 12th-century Koubba. Ambient souks are everywhere and each part of the marketplace is dedicated to a different trade or craft such as carpets, enamel, cedar, leather, brass, camel meat, and other crafts that have been perfected over centuries. There is almost too much for the senses so it’s important to stop at the cafes, where sweet mint tea is poured while you watch the city go about its day.

dayInfo.title: Marrakesh – The Redolent Atmosphere of an Iconic City
dayInfo.description: The next day you will discover that Marrakesh has such an abundance of impressions that only become visible when you take your time. The highlights will enchant you, from the gardens refurbished by Yves St. Laurent, and the mausoleum of a dynasty ruler to museums of crafts and ruins of palaces, plus the remarkable minbar of Koutoubia mosque. Djemaa El-Fna is the city’s central square, a World Heritage space where oral history is transmitted by Berber storytellers and musical groups. You can sit and listen, as well as watching the acrobats and snake charmers that also make a living on the square. All are performers, whether holding a snake or narrating a tale. First they will grab interest as they encourage people to sit with them. Then they will start to narrate, encouraging others to join. Every part of the tale, or each new song, requires a donation from the crowd, with the audience jostling each other to ensure the entertainment continues. For a true insight into the past there are few better cultural experiences. You can combine it with a meal from one of the dozens of food stalls that line the square after dusk.

dayInfo.title: High Atlas Mountains – Exploring Traditional Berber Villages and a Night of Pure Tranquility
dayInfo.description: Oral history is also alive in the villages as stories are passed down through generations in a time-honored way. Hidden in the mountains, these remote villages will offer you an escape from the world, terraced into the mountains with their mud roofs. Colors blur, the baked ochre of the earth against swathes of fertile slopes. Hospitality to strangers remains one of the great tenets of local culture as the villagers welcome visitors with enthusiasm. This village’s culture and landscapes are an inspiring part of the world. You will spend the day crisscrossing through the mountains and stop to discover these old villages, before you stay at a decadent spa escape that’s far from everything. After ten days of exploring Spain and Morocco, it’ll be time to sit back and indulge.

dayInfo.title: High Atlas Mountains – Hiking Spectacular Landscapes and the Serenity of the Moroccan Mountains
dayInfo.description: Today, you will awake to rugged peaks that twist towards the horizon, with a hint of snow only on the highest of them. Valleys stretch onwards beneath your feet and nothing artificial breaks their spell. Villages cling to remote slopes, ever ready to welcome you for a glass of mint tea. For savvy travelers, the High Atlas Mountains are one of the gems of modern travel as they are dramatically beautiful and deserted yet easily accessible for visitors. You will have a mountain guide for the day and the best way to explore will be on foot, with a range of routes possible dependent on your interests and fitness levels, including a one-way routes with a four-wheel drive return transfer. The silence is absolute and the escapism is complete as the High Atlas is a destination for disappearing into both culture and nature.

dayInfo.title: Marrakesh – Departure
dayInfo.description: On your last day in Morocco, the spa retreat will be a short drive back to Marrakesh and the international airport. You’ll be assisted through customs and immigration to avoid any delays as you leave the country.

tourName: 12 Day Northern Morocco: Amazing History, Landscapes, and Cities
placesVisited: Tangier, Chefchaouen, Fes, Tetouan
generalInfo: Venture off the beaten path in northern Morocco during this 12-day adventure. This is the experiential side of Morocco that is full of stories and secrets. Chefchaouen is a blue-washed and baffling city that pulls you under its spell, and Tetouan is an Andalusian-inspired city with a highly unique history. Explore the enchantment of Fes, escape to Morocco’s lesser-known UNESCO World Heritage Sites, and savor the great flavors of the country with a private cooking course.

dayInfo.title: Tangier – A Rich and Beautiful History
dayInfo.description: Civilizations have come and gone in Tangier for more than 2,500 years. You will land at the city’s international airport, and your driver will greet and transfer you to a boutique riad or guesthouse on the coast. When you are ready, you can set off on a city tour that will have you visiting Sh’ar Raphael Synagogue, wandering past a Spanish church, and discussing how the city influenced Beat Generation writers and musicians like The Rolling Stones. You will then immerse yourself in the old medina to see how ornamental stucco fills the lanes and how the Grand Mosque used to be a Portuguese Cathedral.

dayInfo.title: Tangier – Larache, Lixus, and Asilah
dayInfo.description: Civilizations have left their mark along Morocco’s Atlantic Coast with remnants from times of quarrel and takeover. Today, you can stroll through Lixus, which is a vast Roman city that is little more than ruins and rubble. You can listen to stories with your guide as you walk across mosaic floors and enter what remains of the baths and temples. Larache has a bloody history and makes for a good place to discuss the effects of colonialism in northwestern Africa. Next, you will spend the afternoon in Asilah, which is an enchanting town that is draped along the ocean. You will return to Tangier in the late afternoon.

dayInfo.title: Tetouan – A Whitewashed Jewel
dayInfo.description: Tetouan is a dreamy location because it slopes down a river valley toward the calm water of the Alboran Sea. Now a UNESCO World Heritage Site, the city has its origins in the Spanish Inquisition. Moors, Moriscos, and Jews fled Spain, bringing a flavor of Andalusia to a bay that was once populated by pirates. So much more will be revealed as you walk around the old medina with your local guide, from the Bis Mosque to the Spanish Cathedral and the 17th-century Royal Palace. Today’s tour will cover all of the city’s major highlights and stories, including a Moroccan lunch on an alleyway near the fort.

dayInfo.title: Tetouan – A World Heritage Medina
dayInfo.description: Today will be left free, and you will continue to uncover stories as you stroll around Tetouan at your leisure. You can wander along the coast and past the fort to the medina, where the winding streets are packed with sights you may have missed yesterday. During your time here, you will also pick up on the language. Another option for the day will be to walk along the coast, stopping at cafes and restaurants along the way. Despite the city’s UNESCO World Heritage status, Tetouan is far from the tourist trail, and there is an authenticity to the city.

dayInfo.title: Chefchaouen – A Surprising History
dayInfo.description: Today, you will transfer to Chefchaouen, which is a blue and white town nestled in the mountains. Your riad will be in the heart of the fully pedestrianized old town, which is just a few steps from Plaza Uta El-Hammam. You can check-in and then check out the history, beginning at the Kasbah Museum. From the museum’s roof, there is a brilliant view of the town. During your tour, you can wander past patios that are adorned with orange and lemon trees, find harmony in the roof tiles, and bask in the story of Jewish and Muslim immigrants. There are many cafes that you can stop in for a glass of mint tea, and a handful of shops sell the local specialty of woven rugs and blankets.

dayInfo.title: Chefchaouen – Spa Experience and Cooking Class
dayInfo.description: Chefchaouen’s market days provide a poignant insight into local life. The market looks and feels impromptu; it is a swathe of stores that are dotted around the town gate. You will explore it all with a local chef and guide, sampling and purchasing fresh local produce to use in the kitchen. Your guide will know many of the traders, providing you with an excellent opportunity to converse with people from places that do not see tourists. You will take your produce to a local home and learn the secrets of Rif Mountain cuisine. You will cover a couple of Moroccan classics, such as the tajine . After dining, you will have the afternoon at your leisure before an experience in the town’s finest hammam .

dayInfo.title: Chefchaouen – Hiking to the Akchour Waterfalls
dayInfo.description: With three days in Chefchaouen, you will not get bored with walking around the same cobbled lanes. You can leave the town to join the walking trails that will lead you into the Rif Mountains. It is a 40-minute hike to the Akchour Waterfalls. To get here, you must cross a narrow natural bridge. Upon your arrival, the falls will expand, bringing the refreshment of rushing water. Small cafes flank the bottom of the falls so that you can indulge in a glass of mint tea before returning to Chefchaouen. The afternoon will be at your leisure.

dayInfo.title: Fes – Discovering Berber Villages
dayInfo.description: Villages dot the Rif Mountains, which are home to a civilization that is older than the Phoenicians who arrived in the area 3,000 years ago. Speaking their own Riffian language, these Berber communities are distinct from other Berber communities that are found in Morocco. Today, you will stop at two villages en route to Fes. Your guide will help translate as you are welcomed into a home for the ritual of sugary mint tea. The stories have always been shared orally, and there is a passion to the narration that is only usually found when the tales are not written. Eventually, you will arrive in Fes in the early afternoon.

dayInfo.title: Fes – Historical and Cultural Tour of Fes
dayInfo.description: A route through the world’s largest walled city will bring a procession of treasures. Here, you will witness a dazzling palace, the Jewish Mellah, an evocative tomb, and beautiful streets framed by citrus trees. You will then continue past the fruit and the vegetables to the spices. Here, you can enjoy how all of these parts of the souk are busy with locals. You can stop for lunch at a cafe terrace in the heart of the maze, which is ideal for people watching while eating. Afterward, you will venture through the Dyers Souk and Tanner’s Quarters to a breathtaking 14th-century madrassa.

dayInfo.title: Fes – Volubilis, Moulay Idriss, and Meknes
