dayInfo.description: Today, you will enter Moulay Idriss through a monumental gate and wander past its beautiful Koranic schools and fountains. This was Morocco’s first Islamic city, and it was founded by the great-grandson of prophet Mohamed, Moulay Idriss. Although non-Muslims are not permitted within the Tomb of Moulay Idriss, you will get a good understanding of the engrossing spirituality within the city. Two UNESCO World Heritage Sites are nearby. You will complete your morning in Volubilis, which is an evocative Roman city in much better shape than Lixus. You will then travel to Meknes for lunch and spend your afternoon in this imperial city. Artisanal and atmospheric, the Meknes medina can feel like a living art gallery.

dayInfo.title: Fes – Unique Foodie Tour
dayInfo.description: This final day will allow you to witness the highlights of outer Fes with mostly gardens and palaces. You will explore Dar El-Batha Museum and then discover the most iconic of all Fassi architecture in Palais Mokri. You will stop for lunch at a cafe that overlooks a garden before a free afternoon allows you to create your own stories within the medina. Like everywhere else in Morocco, you will never stop exploring with your eyes. Fes will leave an impression on each of your senses.

dayInfo.title: Fes – Departure
dayInfo.description: Fes is somewhat calmed in the morning. You will spend your final morning enjoying the streets or visiting one of the stores that you spotted on a guided tour. Late check-out will be arranged at your riad , and you will transfer to the airport for your homebound flight before noon.

placesVisited: Marrakech, Dades Gorges, Sahara, Ouarzazate
generalInfo: Discover and experience the majesty of ancient traditions, spirited colors, and captivating scenery during your 8-day Morocco Highlights tour. Embrace the luxuries of traditional riads and explore the detailed opulence of former palaces. Travel across the Sahara’s renowned sand dunes and wander through the narrow lanes of an authentic medina. From desert nights with star-studded skies to shops filled with aromatic spices, you will find the wonders of Morocco.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech - Arrive in Morocco to Find Marrakech
dayInfo.description: A center for artisanal heritage and the point at which historic culture and preserved faith meet, Marrakech is a captivating city where the rhythms of the marketplace permeate daily life. Your flight will arrive at the Marrakech airport, where your private transfer will meet you upon arrival. You will have plenty of time to relax in the comforts of your luxury accommodation in the heart of the city and freshen up at your leisure. In the evening, you can take part in the lively ambiance of Djemaa El Fna Square as the plaza erupts with storytellers, musicians, and food vendors.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech - Explore the Monuments of Marrakech
dayInfo.description: After breakfast, your private transfer will meet you at the hotel and lead you on a discovery of the city’s remarkable monuments. At the Palais Bahia, you may find a vibrant design that reminds you of a peacock with zellige tiles, painted ceilings, and wrought-iron finishes that embody opulence. The scent of oranges may drift from the citrus trees in the courtyard. In the afternoon, you will continue into the twisting narrow lanes of the medina where you may find fragrant spice stalls, colorful textiles, and glinting brass light fixtures in the souk.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech - Enjoy Sunrise and a Cooking Class
dayInfo.description: In the early morning, you will venture outside of the city to reach an open field where you can step into a hot-air balloon. As the sun rises over the cityscape, you will have an unforgettable panorama of the colors spreading across the sky, land, and city. The combination of cool morning air and vibrant natural color will create an everlasting memory. In the afternoon, you will have a chef lead you through the steps of cooking a traditional Moroccan tagine. You will learn how to properly season and braise chicken for an aromatic and rich cultural flavor.

dayInfo.title: Dades Gorge - Discover the High Atlas Mountains
dayInfo.description: Your private transfer will meet you at the hotel in the morning and lead you out of Marrakech to reach the Dades Gorge. The scenic drive will take you along the twisting roads of Morocco’s deep and colorful canyon as you uncover the ancient layers of the landscape and the historic Kasbahs along the former rich trade route. You may stop at Ait Youl to find the view overlooking the mountains and a panorama of the switchback leading deeper to the valley floor. Once in the gorge, you may find the scent of fruit orchards that contrast the rugged rock formations.

dayInfo.title: Sahara - Travel to the Desert for a Sunset Tour
dayInfo.description: You will continue your scenic drive to reach Merzouga and the rolling sand dunes of the Sahara Desert. The image exemplifies one of the many pictures of Morocco and captures the dreamscape of the majestic desert. As the sun begins to set, you can ride a camel along the dunes to watch the sands shift from gold to orange to red before starlight takes over the sky. Your luxury camping experience will immerse you in the soothing sounds of the desert accompanied by the sounds of the crackling fire.

dayInfo.title: Ouarzazate - Experience Sunrise and a Desert City
dayInfo.description: In the early morning, you can rise to the scent of mint tea and watch the sunrise over the dunes. The colors may shift from blue to pink and then back to pale orange as the sun fills the sky. Your private transfer will meet you after breakfast and escort you to the sand-castle city of Ouarzazate. The historic Kasbah and former French colonial garrison town offers a great place to view the sandy walls rising out of the mountains and overlook the shimmering oasis waters or the desert plain.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech - Traverse Benhaddou and Enjoy Marrakech
dayInfo.description: The morning air may entice you to join an ATV excursion through the desert to reach the historic city of Ait Benhaddou. The surrounding desert landscape can feel vast and brimming with beautiful drama with the village architecture blending into the surrounding scenery. The fortified village may feel frozen in time as a film set decorated with orange walls and lush almond trees. You can climb to the top of the Kasbah turrets for an impressive view over the village, the surrounding palm grove, and the unforgiving features of the stony desert beyond.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech - Depart for Home
dayInfo.description: The life of Marrakech will return to the streets of the medina in the morning. If you have time, you may visit one of the monuments at your own pace to enjoy the life of the city once more. When you are ready, your private transfer will meet you at the hotel and escort you to Casablanca for your flight home. You will have plenty of time to check-in at the airport bringing an end to your discovery of Morocco’s highlights.

tourName: A Perfect Morocco Family Vacation Package
placesVisited: Ouarzazate, Tazzarine, Sahara Desert, Marrakech, Aït Ben Haddou
generalInfo: The desert landscape draws you in with golden sands and rising dunes. Palaces constructed from clay continue to tower over the expansive flatland. Mountain passes flourish with cedar trees and hints of spices. This custom tailored vacation will captivate the entire family, telling tales of timeless culture and remote fortresses. Camels leave hoof prints in the soft soil and oases blossom out of the desolate landscape. Your children will marvel at the exotic snake charmers and find life similar to legend brimming inside ancient city walls.

dayInfo.title: Ouarzazate – Whisking the Family A World Away
dayInfo.description: The world becomes new with your arrival in Ouarzazate, Morocco. The city has been nicknamed the “Door of the Desert,” and sits between three different valleys. The town is filled with Berbers, the predominant indigenous people of North Africa. The earthen buildings shimmer gold in the drifting sunlight. The kids will think they have arrived in a desert palace, surrounded by historic walls and filled with exotic culture. Ouarzazate has been featured in films from Lawrence of Arabia to Gladiator. The city maintains a feeling of importance, having once been the main stopping point on the trans-Saharan trade route. The souk bustles with people at all hours of the day, filled with traders that once came all the way from Timbuktu. The city is filled with meandering aromas, from the arid desert earth to the nearby lush valleys, to the aromatics of couscous emanating from homes. Atlas Movie Studios is situated nearby and has helped dress historical fiction on the big screen for decades. The kids feel like they have stepped into a movie themselves, eager to journey out into the surrounding landscape and search for hidden culture, buried treasure, or ancient civilizations. The wonders of Morocco turn every moment into possible inspiration.

dayInfo.title: Tazzarine – An Imaginative Oases
dayInfo.description: The morning sun sweeps across the city and casts an inviting light over the golden buildings of Taourirt Kasbah. Historic walls surround the old city built by the Glaoui family. The palace inside the walled city was once the home of the Glaoui chiefs. Mountains fill the distant horizon; the kids are excited to enter the old city walls. Geometric drawings decorate the ramparts and wind down the inner alleys and gateways. Towers and turrets pack single-family homes tightly together, amidst a collection of up to 20 different historic family mansions. A soft, warm breeze sweeps through the deserted streets. A myriad of stairwells creates a mysterious, almost abandoned atmosphere, in the fortress grounds. The children creep quietly through the meandering alleyways like treasure hunters. They find oddly shaped rooms illuminated by large, open windows. The plasterwork is cut into floral patterns to decorate the larger rooms. Cedar wood panels cover the ceilings. The remnants of opulence fill the rooms and the entire Kasbah, restored as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The family makes its way out away from the old walls where your private transfer escorts you through the heights of the Tizi n’Tichka Pass, at around 7,415 feet, and on to the Oasis of Tazzarine.

dayInfo.title: Tazzarine – Embracing Desert Lands
dayInfo.description: The desert landscape is dotted with pockets of lush greenery emanating from swaying palm trees. The desert air is cool in the morning light. Mountains roll across the landscape. Henna fields rise out of the fertile earth and make the barren desert almost disappear. The nearby petroglyphs of Aït Ouazik contain history dating back to 5,000 BC. They contain images of elephants, giraffes, and antelope, when the landscape was believed to have attributes of the savanna. Foum Tizza is a rarely visited dune field on the outskirts of the oasis. The picturesque Sahel contrasts soft, sifting sand with blue-black rocks strewn across the expanse. You arrive at your transportation and the kids almost cry out in anticipation. A camel train awaits you to climb aboard before venturing into the depths of the Sahara on a luxury excursion. The camel gets up back legs first before standing at its full height of over seven feet tall. The kids yelp when it’s their turn. You watch them sway from side to side as the camel walks through the desert sand. Bedouins wave as they pass you by. Their cobalt blue robes stand out against the surrounding pale sands. As the daylight fades the drivers pull out drums, singing to the beat with a tune that sounds equal parts expression and prayer.

dayInfo.title: Tazzarine – Nature’s Source
dayInfo.description: The family is up before the sun. The air is cold and calm around you. The stoic beauty of the desert becomes illuminated when the sun starts to rise. Light spreads in layers of deep red and orange. The sand changes from a distant darkness to vibrant pink, and eventually turns gold. The family watches in awe, reluctant to turn away. The aroma of mint tea mingles with scents of breakfast. The cup of tea warms your hand as the sunshine spreads across the expanse. After your meal, the family climbs back up on their camels to venture back into the oasis. The breeze shifts the sand around the camel’s toes. You look back and see the lingering trail the train left in the sand. The camel prints intersect with other prints that you can barely discern. You ask the guide what animal the small footprints belong to. He tells you about the Fennec Fox, a nocturnal mammal that can grow up to 17 inches long. They have large, bat-like ears and angular, black eyes. The kids listen with awe to the variety of animals that can survive the extreme temperatures of the desert. You take in the breathtaking landscape as it starts to shift from widespread sands to the return of rising palms and far-reaching henna fields.

dayInfo.title: Aït Ben Haddou – Strengthening Bonds
dayInfo.description: At breakfast, the kids reminisce about their favorite moments in the desert. You laugh at their impersonations of their camels, as they shake their heads from side to side and grunt. The fragrant mint tea has become a source of comfort and familiarity in your on-going adventure through the Moroccan landscape. When the meal is done and the kids have grown tired of their camel impersonations, your private transfer escorts you to Aït Ben Haddou, the largest Kasbah in Morocco. Pass through Draa Valley with over 60 miles of date palms. The sweet aroma passes by with a background of the lunar Kissane Mountain Range. The fortified walls are a proud and prominent red, strengthened by interspersed towers. Slit windows adorn the upper parts of the walls for guards to see out, but threatening armies or raiders unable to see in. The city rises up the small mountain. A granary stands at the top of the mountain and offers the best view of the historic city below, and the copious rolling mountains all around. Once again the kids feel as though they have entered a movie, when in fact they are walking through history, with the oldest constructs dating back to the 17th century. The earthen buildings remain firm and inspiring. The clay helps keep the homes cool in the desert sun. Around every corner, the kids turn with anticipation. You aren’t sure what they expect to find but you know they are having fun searching.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – Surpassing the Mountains
dayInfo.description: The red clay city continues to fill the family’s thoughts. Orange zest adds a unique aroma and flavor to the comforts of mint tea accompanying breakfast. The kids want more time to explore the depths of Aït Ben Haddou and its cinematic streets. After breakfast your private transfer meets you. The rustic city disappears behind the barren hills as you ascend the High Atlas Mountains. The Tizi n’Tichka Pass has not changed in centuries, continuing to meander through the mountains. The village of Imlil stands on the foothills. The mountains are textured with irrigated terraces. The peak of Mount Toubkal towers over the village at an elevation of 13,671 feet. Visitors often use Imlil as a starting point for treks into the mountains. As you descend the mountain, the outline of Marrakech comes into view. The historic red walls surround the medina. The large gate known as Bab Agnaou once stood as the main entryway into the city. The sandstone walls border an arched doorway. Layers of a shell design encircle the arch. You enter the city and find a world of imagination in Djemaa el Fna Square. People lounge on colorful pillows in rooftop cafes and watch the active plaza below. The kids are as entranced as the serpents when watching the snake charmers play their songs and weave to the instrumentals. Magicians disappear in flashes of light and puffs of smoke. The kids eagerly listen to a storyteller spinning yarns of genies, tales that are both familiar and new all at once. The aroma of spices and simmering kebabs wafts from the many food stalls that fill the square in the evening. The city has already cast its enchantment over the family.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – Family Legend
dayInfo.description: The soothing rhythm of the Call to Prayer echoes through the medina streets. The city comes alive with the soft-spoken words and calm cadence. After breakfast, your guide meets you at the hotel and the kids are more than ready to venture out into the medina streets once more. The souk overflows with activity, ranging from vendors selling rugs taller than your children to babouches , pointy-toed shoes, lining shop walls. Stroll past endless rows of spices that the kids want to dip their fingers into. They fight the urge to blow on the fragrant seasonings like fairy dust. The stone pathways pass underneath stone buildings and alongside vibrantly painted doors. Bahia Palace was constructed in the 19th century and held the vivacious inspiration of a peacock’s plumage. The sultan had a variety of artists decorate the large expanse of rooms, courtyard, and gardens to dazzle foreign dignitaries, and showcase the opulent lives of nobility. Shady, sprawling trees stand beside sumptuous blossoming flowers. The pathway in the main courtyard is laid with geometric grace encircling a series of fountains. The upper walls contain latticework framed by a cedar colonnade. The mystical tales told by the storyteller the previous day have a more palpable them when exploring the remaining luxuries of the palace.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – Leaving Impressions
dayInfo.description: The spirit of Morocco is displayed effortlessly in Marrakech, winding through the spellbinding medina at all hours of the day. The High Atlas Mountains climb along the horizon. The calls of Djemaa el Fna Square start to rise in the morning sun. You indulge in the warmth of the comforting flavors of mint tea and listen to your children imitate the storytellers and try to create their own myths inspired by the Moroccan landscape and culture. After breakfast, your private transfer meets you at the hotel and escorts the family to the airport. The wonders of Morocco have enchanted the entire family and have given proven to be much more tangible and inspiring than a mirage. Visit Zicasso's Morocco tours page for more vacation planning ideas.

tourName: Adventurous 10-Day Luxury Tour of Morocco for Seniors
placesVisited: Rabat, Fez, Meknes, Volubilis, High Atlas Mountains, Marrakesh, Oualidia, Essaouira
generalInfo: Take off on a 10-day Morocco trip for seniors to enjoy an excursion into the mystical beauty of northern Africa. Explore historic and religious landmarks of centuries past, weave in and out of the winding labyrinths, immerse yourself in artisan workshops, and journey to the summit of the country’s highest peak. From fame to hidden gems, you will find the true wonders of Morocco.

dayInfo.title: Rabat - Arrive in Morocco and Tour Hassan II Mosque
dayInfo.description: Touch down along the sparkling coastlines of Casablanca at the Mohamed V International Airport. On your first day in Morocco you can stroll through the stunning Hassan II Mosque, built by the late King Hassan II at the end of his 40-year reign. Marvel at the stoic beauty nestled alongside the Atlantic Coast before your private transfer escorts you to Rabat to visit the capital and one of the ancient imperial cities. Discover the grandeur of the historic city gate that continues to project the Medina as you arrive in the city’s quiet charm.

dayInfo.title: Rabat - Explore the Heritage of Morocco
dayInfo.description: Partake in a light breakfast at the hotel the following morning, before meeting your expert guide outside your hotel. Your tour of Rabat will uncover the mystical labyrinths of the Kasbah des Oudaias alleyways and the white stucco homes stacked closely together. Climb to the top of the Kasbah for panoramic views of the Atlantic Ocean, as well as the entrance to the harbor of Rabat and Sale. Continue to the Mohamed V Mausoleum to find the final resting place of King Mohammed, guarded by the mounted Royal Household Guard, where you view Hassan Tower, an unfinished 12th-century minaret.

dayInfo.title: Fez - Uncover Historical Fez
dayInfo.description: Explore the city of Fez, a stunning UNESCO World Heritage Site, founded in the 9th century. Marvel at the revered historical monuments in the medina, including fondouks, palaces, residences, mosques, and fountains. Immerse yourself in the wonder of an artisan workshop, as active today as they were 100 years ago. Witness the incredible details and careful craftsmanship of the country's finest metal and leatherwork, ceramics, silk, tapestries, and sculpting. Marvel at the intricate blue-green tilework of the Splendid Fountain at Place Nejjarine and stroll through the narrow, vibrant halls of The Mellah, the city's Jewish Quarter.

dayInfo.title: High Atlas - Venture to the Incredible High Atlas Mountains
dayInfo.description: Spend the morning at your leisure, either relaxing at the hotel, strolling through town, shopping for souvenirs, or sipping tea at a local cafe as you take in the views. Your driver will pick you up from the hotel in the late morning hours, where you'll transfer to the airport in Fez and catch a flight to Marrakesh. Enjoy your luxury accommodations at a five-star hotel in the High Atlas Mountains at the base of Mount Toubkal, the highest peak in Morocco. Unwind with a free afternoon in your kasbah hotel's gardens or go for a short hike nearby.

dayInfo.title: High Atlas - Enjoy Time at Leisure In the High Atlas
dayInfo.description: You will begin the day with breakfast at the hotel. Then, uncover the breathtaking beauty of the High Atlas Mountains on a self-guided trek through the exquisite terrain. Discover ancient terraced farms, which were cut into the rugged mountains hundreds of years ago so even the most remote villages could harvest and grow crops, despite the steep incline of the land. Breathe in the crisp air of this lush oasis as you look out on the looming mountain peaks in the distance. Then explore the small mountain towns nestled between peaks or enjoy a scenic camel ride into the sunset.

dayInfo.title: Marrakesh - Discover the Charms of Marrakesh
dayInfo.description: Enjoy a restful morning at your own pace before transferring to Marrakesh. Check in at your luxury hotel before exploring the city. Jemaa el-Fna is a large, open-air square at the heart of Marrakesh, as old as the city itself. It demonstrates the city's cultural epicenter, home to a frenzy of activity at all hours of the day and night, including snake charmers, henna artists, herbalists, acrobats, and musicians. Buildings around the main square offer alluring rooftop cafes and restaurants that overlook the bustling plaza and its charismatic entertainers.

dayInfo.title: Marrakesh - Enjoy a Cultural and Historic Tour
dayInfo.description: Meet your guide in the hotel lobby the following morning to partake in a private tour of Marrakesh. As you enter downtown, you may become mesmerized by the array of warm yellows, oranges, and pinks beckoning you down the quaint cobbled streets of the historic center. Begin the tour at the Koutoubia Minaret, the centerpiece of Marrakesh and an ode to the country's proud, long-held Islamic history. Then stroll amongst the Saadian Tombs, flanked by beautiful gardens, two mausoleums, and more than a hundred mosaic-decorated tombs.

dayInfo.title: Essaouira - Delight In Time at Your Leisure
dayInfo.description: Take off the next morning to beautiful Essaouira. On the way you'll pass through the heart of Morocco's famous nut-growing region as you near the coast. Once in Mogador you'll explore Essaouira’s blue and white medina, revered as a UNESCO World Heritage site. Learn about the former Portuguese stronghold and trading outpost that became the city’s artistic center. You can also stroll along the enchanting streets and alleys to enjoy the ambiance of the labyrinthine design pressed against the sea. You can scale the nearby stairs for 360-degree views of Essaouira in the Moulay El Hassan square.

dayInfo.title: Oualidia - Revel and Explore at Your Pace
dayInfo.description: Enjoy a leisurely breakfast before traveling to the stunning coastal town of Oualidia along the Atlantic. You will have the remainder of the day to visit Oualidia's protected lagoon to view flocks of pink flamingos or enjoy the region’s famous oysters. You can even dip your toes into the refreshing cool water of the lagoon's oasis. Travel to a boutique resort overlooking the oasis to unwind in the comforts of the desert light and shade. Admire the waning sunset hand-in-hand as you soak in the beauty of your final evening in Morocco.

dayInfo.title: Oualidia - Depart for Home
dayInfo.description: Meet your driver outside your hotel for your private transfer to the airport for the last time. At the Mohamed V Airport in Casablanca you'll be escorted to your departing gate, before boarding your international flight home. As you and your partner peer out the window, you can think back to the refreshing Atlantic breeze in the lovely coastal town of Oualidia and the exciting frenzy of activity in Marrakesh for fond memories of your travels in enchanting Morocco.

placesVisited: Marrakech, Fes, Ouarzazate, Merzouga
generalInfo: Handcrafted with Morocco’s most intimate cultural experiences, this one-week tour will lead you from Berber villages to Gnawa backroads and artisanal cities to glasses of mint tea in ancient medinas. Morocco is a melting pot of fascinating cultures, where traditions ring true, and heritage is part of daily life. This is a journey that is defined by the people you meet and the traditions you can experience, from Marrakech to the Sahara Desert.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – Berber Storytelling
dayInfo.description: Today, you will land in Marrakech and be greeted at the airport by a local guide. It is a short transfer to your centrally located hotel, where you will have time to rest and refresh before gathering your first impressions of the mazy streets. Rather than visit set attractions, today’s Marrakech walk will focus on absorbing the atmosphere. So, you can wander the lively labyrinthine streets and use all your senses to admire what is happening before an evening of sunset colors and Berber traditions on the main square.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – Highlights of an Imperial City
dayInfo.description: With a full day in Marrakech, you can explore the city’s history and tradition. Starting your private tour on the city’s outskirts, you will explore palaces and tombs, which are classic examples of Berber and Arab influences. After lunch, you will travel into the medina, where you will be immersed in the souks, which are sensual places of strange sounds and wonderful aromas. You can spend hours here, wandering a marketplace that is far more enchanting than any modern supermarket. Marrakech’s souks are a great example of how you can experience culture in Morocco.

dayInfo.title: Ouarzazate – Exploring Berber Villages
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will visit with small Berber communities, and your guide will be from one of them. Therefore, you will have an intimate invitation into the local life. This part of Morocco deserves time, and everything runs to a slow rhythm, so you should not expect to rush. Just enjoy the experience without thinking about time. After enjoying lunch in a Berber village, you will continue to the Sahara. Ait Benhaddou is the oldest and best-preserved of all the mud-brick kasbahs and now enjoys UNESCO World Heritage status. You will eventually make your way to Ouarzazate, which is your overnight destination. Ouarzazate is a gateway to the Sahara and a great place for basking in the Berber culture.

dayInfo.title: Merzouga – Intimate Experiences
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will travel the Road of the Thousand Kasbahs. The desert scenery is dominated by fairytale-like castles that rise red from the dust. Throughout the afternoon, you will visit small caravanserai and hopefully share mint tea with people about to cross the desert. These encounters are almost as fascinating as an evening with the Gnawa, which is a group of people who came across the Sahara from Sudan. This evening, you will be in the Sahara, immersed in a community of people that keeps ancient cultural traditions alive.

dayInfo.title: Fes – The Sahara At Sunrise
dayInfo.description: With the sun barely peeking over the horizon, you will travel by camel to the sand dunes, crossing the virgin sand to places of great solitude and silence. By mid-morning, you will be out of the dunes and on a flight to Fes, which is the world’s largest walled city. Fes is enormous, and culture spills from every corner of its city center. Tanners continue their ancient ways, locals meet for glasses of mint tea at small medina cafes, and mosques and madrassas create a sense of peace on the city streets. You do not need to plan anything specific here because a local guide will show around so that you can experience some of the very best aspects of Arab culture.

dayInfo.title: Fes – Artisanal Culture in Meknes
dayInfo.description: While Fes is the grandest of the imperial cities, Meknes is mostly forgotten. Meknes is Morocco’s artisanal city, and local artisans do not pay any tax. So, everything you will see is a work of art. In Meknes, you will have the opportunity to meet with artisans and understand how art is so integral to culture. If you think of beautiful Moroccan design, there is a good chance it has its origins in this imperial city. It is this artistic element of culture you will explore today. Returning to Fes with your guide, you can stop at Volubilis, which is a fabulous set of Roman. Back in Fes, it will be all about the atmosphere as you sip on mint tea.

dayInfo.title: Fes – Departure
dayInfo.description: This morning will be left free so that you can get out among the souks to find souvenirs with your guide. Late check out will be arranged so that you can refresh after lunch before a private airport transfer.

tourName: Ancient Heritage to Hot Sands: Immersive Morocco Tour
placesVisited: Marrakech, Erg Chigaga, Essaouira
generalInfo: Perched at the northeastern coast of Africa, Morocco presents a gateway to the solitary beauty and rustic communities of the Sahara desert, and this 11-day tour of the country present you with a parade of stunning landscapes and unforgettable experiences. As you make your way from the interior of Morocco to the photogenic coastline, you will be immersed in the culture and heritage of Morocco.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – A World Heritage Site
dayInfo.description: Tucked near the foothills of the Atlas Mountains, Marrakech is an excellent ambassador for the rugged charm and beauty of the interior of Morocco. When your flight lands, you will plunge into the vibrant city with a convenient transfer. The medina district of Marrakech was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1985 and will be yours to enjoy during your stay. Upon your arrival to your comfortable accommodation, the remainder of the day will be yours to spend however you see fit.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – A City that Time Forgot
dayInfo.description: As dawn touches the minarets that punctuate the skyline, you will have the option to rise with the sun and witness the city awaken or to hit the snooze button and continue your restful slumber. Today, you will enjoy breakfast before celebrating your first full day on this vacation with a guided walking tour of the medina district. With the prayer call periodically echoing across the city, your tour will include stunning attractions, such as the Bahia Palace, Koutoubia mosque, and some massive city squares.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – Leisure in the City
dayInfo.description: Marrakech presents visitors with a rich culture heritage that dates back to its Berber origins. Nowhere is this culture best seen than in the medina and outdoor market. At this market, the bountiful produce of Morocco's thriving agricultural sector will be yours to enjoy as well as the ingredients required for the savory cuisine you will have enjoyed since your arrival. You will have the day to explore Marrakech at your own pace and to enjoy an optional cooking course, during which the Moroccan tradition of gastronomy will be revealed.

dayInfo.title: Skoura – Morocco's Highest Waterfall
dayInfo.description: You will plunge into the desert by turning your back on the vibrant charm of Marrakech in search of a comfortable oasis. After breakfast at your hotel, a transfer will lead you on your journey up and over the Atlas Mountains. During this journey, you will stop at the highest waterfall in the country, where the Oued Tissakht River plunges over a massive gorge. A guide will accompany you on this excursion. Afterward, you will continue to your boutique hotel in the Skoura Oasis.

dayInfo.title: Skoura – An Oasis Getaway
dayInfo.description: As far as scenic views and panoramas go, Skoura is an excellent gateway to the region's magnificent castles, canyons, and cliffs. After breakfast, you will choose from a menu of activities to make the most of your first full day in this desert oasis. A trip to the nearby Dades Gorge will introduce you to the nomadic heritage and the impressive network of caves on your way to Boutaghrar. The alternative will be a visit to the nearby Kasbah of Amehidil, where a local guide will introduce you to this impressive castle.

dayInfo.title: Erg Chigaga – Glamping in the Sahara
dayInfo.description: Despite your proximity to the desert, you may be surprised at the lack of sand dunes during your Moroccan travels. That mystery will be solved when you depart Skoura and plunge into the Shara desert and Erg Chigaga, the largest collection of sand dunes in Morocco. After passing through the Draa Valley, you will enjoy a stop at the old Ksar at Tamnougalt before continuing your transfer to the Erg Chigaga. You can conclude your day with a relaxing sunset camel ride, during which you can watch the desert colors change.

dayInfo.title: Ait Benhaddou – An Authentic Moroccan Ksar
dayInfo.description: With few trees to interrupt, the morning light will break evenly across the Sahara Desert as you wake. This morning, you will enjoy breakfast with a view in the desert. The parade of panoramic views will continue when you depart the Erg for the fortified Ksar of Benhaddou while enjoying a scenic transfer that will include numerous clay castles, and views of the Atlas Mountains and Ounila Valley. Upon your arrival, you will have the remainder of the day at your leisure to enjoy this rustic community.

dayInfo.title: Essaouira – Where the Sand Meets the Sea
dayInfo.description: As dawn breaks on Ait Benhaddou, it will reveal a rustic community of clay bricks, wood, and earth, demonstrating the town's reliance on local construction materials. Today, your tour of landlocked communities will cease when you depart the Ounila valley and make your way to the shores of the Atlantic Ocean. After a leisurely breakfast, a transfer will convey you to your final destination of Essaouria. Along the way, you can enjoy stops at the numerous kasbahs and palaces before reaching your seaside accommodation.

dayInfo.title: Essaouira – Making the Most of this Seaside Paradise
dayInfo.description: Essaouira presents visitors with an excellent playground for outdoor recreation in this beautiful landscape. After a leisurely morning, you can partake in a number of options to make the most of your privileged position. A medina walking tour will introduce you to the city of Essaouira and the charming outdoor market where fresh fish and other wares are sold. The nearby Sidi Kaouki beach allows for horseback riding, quad excursions, or watersports for those who seek sun-drenched thrills.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – Returning to the Regional Capital
dayInfo.description: Your circuit of Moroccan destinations will conclude when you depart the coastal beauty of Essaouira and make your way back to Marrakech for the final leg of your travels. After a leisurely morning, you will begin your journey with an optional stop at an authentic Moroccan winery. Here, the precious land is used to cultivate some award-winning vintages. In the afternoon, your transfer will drop you off at your hotel, where you will have the remainder of the day to enjoy at your leisure.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – Departure
dayInfo.description: On your final morning in Marrakech, you will have just enough time to enjoy a final amble along the corridors and narrow lanes of the medina to capture some final snapshots and memories. For the last ten days, you will have enjoyed an off-the-beaten-path exploration of Morocco and the rich culture and history found here. After breakfast, a comfortable transfer will drive you to the nearby airport for your return flight.

tourName: Art and Soul of Morocco Luxury Tour
placesVisited: Fes, Meknes, Chefchaouen
generalInfo: This 10-day tour in the northern triangle of destinations celebrates both heritage and design, while riad accommodations enhance the feel of the past. Journey into Morocco’s heartlands as art and soul come together in centuries-old destinations. Imagine atmospheric towns with exquisite décor, dramatic landscapes, and the decadence of a blud city. Explore Fes for icons and surprises, Meknes for intricate art and stories, and Chefchaouen for a blissful break amid five centuries of tradition.

dayInfo.title: Fes – Gazing at the Minarets
dayInfo.description: You will touch down at Fes’ international airport. Fes sits in a natural bowl with seemingly endless swathes of whitewashed buildings that rise from its slopes. The city is a baffling sight from above, especially with the profusion of satellite dishes that mark all the flat roofs. Minarets and domes dot the cityscape. Your initial view of the city will provide an impression of the city’s scale before you descend into it. You will check in to your boutique riad before enjoying an orientation tour with your guide.

dayInfo.title: Fes – Intimate Foodie Tour
dayInfo.description: Today, you will follow the many aromas through the alleyways of Fes, tracing the scent of spices and street food. You can sample wild honey in a honey souk, try spicy sardines and potato from a street cart, and enjoy piles of olives at a bustling marketplace. With food as a focus, you will be immersed in the day to day life of Fes and its people. Of course, you will wander through the spice bazaar and sample dozens of tantalizing flavors. In the afternoon, you can discover another side to the city with a Jewish heritage tour that showcases both the monuments and the stories.

dayInfo.title: Fes – The History of an Imperial City
dayInfo.description: With several days in Fes, it is best to save the history and the art for last. With so much happening in the medina, a historical tour can initially get overwhelming. You will begin your tour at the Palace Gates of the King and Madrasa Bou Inania. Here, you can witness superb evocations from the Marinid dynasty. Zaouia Moulay Idriss and Karaouine University will provide an idea of Fes in its formative Idrisid dynasty years. You will then move to Nejjarine Square. Along the way, you can explore the Chouara Tannery, Dyers Souk, the pottery cooperatives, gardens, palace facades, and all the intricate historical details that make Fes so special.

dayInfo.title: Meknes – Morocco’s Spiritual Soul
dayInfo.description: Volubilis stands in ruins; it is a city that continues to keep watch as it softly crumbles. You can sense the grandeur in the reconstructed columns and feel the beauty on the 2,000-year-old avenues. This was a massive city, and you will have time to walk around what remains of its shell. Much of the stone was plundered to build Moulay Idriss, which is the site where Islam was introduced to Northwest Africa. You can explore this Islamic city. Although you cannot enter Moulay Idriss’s mausoleum, this city has a fascinating mix of pilgrims, peace, and proud locals. These two destinations are en route to Meknes, and your first afternoon in this Imperial city will be at your leisure.

dayInfo.title: Meknes – Grandeur and Grace
dayInfo.description: After breakfast, you will transfer to Koubba el-Khayatine, which is where your tour will begin before continuing to Dar el Makhzen. All of these monuments have a distinctive style that you will immediately recognize as Moroccan. Within the city’s heart, you will find a procession of mosques, palaces, madrassas, and mausoleums. Sometimes, it is difficult to find a square meter without artistic designs. Artisanal production is not taxed in Meknes, so even the poorest medina homes are imbued with intricate details. You will complete the day’s tour by browsing the souks to see the artisans at work.

dayInfo.title: Meknes – Artist Tour of an Artisanal City
dayInfo.description: Today, you will indulge in an artistic tour of an artistic city, which will begin inside the Mausoleum of Moulay Ismail. Here, you can marvel at the intricate geometric patterns transferring to Dar Jamai, which is a 19th-century palace that is now home to the Museum of Moroccan Art. Sculptures, paintings, and changing exhibits make this a superb space to trace the development of Islamic and Moroccan art. You can have a traditional meze lunch before searching for the exquisite calligraphy at Bou Inania Madrasa. Your guide will then lead you through the souks to see artisans at work before ending the tour with a damasquinerie workshop.

dayInfo.title: Chefchaouen – The Blue Pearl
dayInfo.description: After two imperial cities have aroused your senses, you will travel into the Rif Mountains. Your destination will be Chefchaouen, but you will first pass through the land of the Riffians. These Berber people have their own language and history that you can intimately explore when you are invited into a Riffian village and home. Here, you can sip on steaming mint tea, discuss the region’s proud history, and learn how self-sufficient mountain life has hardly changed for millennia. Soon, you will arrive in Chefchaouen. Tomorrow, you will enjoy a guided tour, but today, you will have the evening to wander the town at your leisure.

dayInfo.title: Chefchaouen – Moroccan Cooking Class
dayInfo.description: Perhaps the only Chefchaouen building that is not painted white and blue is the Grand Mosque. Instead, it is a pale red color that is made unique by its minaret. This is a town with hidden stories and quiet gems. You will begin to explore it all at the Kasbah Museum, where you will receive an overview of the city’s life and times. There is a small art gallery in the museum that highlights the craftsmanship for which Chefchaouen is famous. You can piece together the Moorish and the Arab influences at Plaza Uta el-Hammam before wandering through one of Morocco’s finest souks. After half a day of exploring, you will enter a hammam .

dayInfo.title: Chefchaouen – Rif Mountain Adventure
dayInfo.description: The final morning of this art and soul vacation will be spent in the Rif Mountains. These lush mountains extend in all directions from Chefchaouen, providing some of the finest hiking trails on the continent. Many of them leave from a gate at the top of the kasbah, and the 45-minute journey to the Akchour Waterfalls is the most popular. Here, you can cross a natural rock arch or jump into the rock pools. You will have a guide in the morning, and there are various other options for your hike. In the afternoon, you can spend the rest of the day at your leisure.

dayInfo.title: Chefchaouen – Departure
dayInfo.description: From Chefchaouen, you will have a two-hour drive back to Fes. Depending on your flight time, there may be a chance to stop in the Fes souks for some last-minute souvenirs. Afterward, you will transfer to the airport for your outbound flight.

tourName: Best of Marrakech, Essaouira & Ouarzazate Tour
placesVisited: Marrakech, Essaouira, Ouarzazate, Kik Plateau
generalInfo: The best stories never end and instead continue off the page. Morocco is a land built from fairytales, set in the landscape at the foothills of the Atlas Mountains, pressing against the Atlantic Ocean, and moving across the Sahara Desert. Explore the far reaches of the stories that live in the culture and heritage of the country. Embrace the landscapes and let the rhythm of Marrakech enchant you. This custom tailored tour provides the storybook vacation the entire family will enjoy. When myths and legends come to life, all you need to do is relish the adventure.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – The Joys of Marrakech
dayInfo.description: Adventure comes in many forms and when you can discover the world with your family, there is no better experience. Your make your way to the airport to catch your flight to the unique world of Morocco. The possibilities of the country fascinate the kids and delight you. You can imagine the blue painted walls of Medina. The characteristic spices line the market place and add rainbow colors to the cityscape. The kids think of sultans and castles, desert battles and regal horses. Morocco encompasses the splendor of the seaside and the rugged majesty of the mountains. The entire family is enraptured by the persistent traditions, ready to see the mosques and colorful robes in person. The closer the plane moves towards Morocco the more excited the children, the more tangible the culture, and the more enchanting the possibilities. Welcome to the exotic North African city, filled with the enrapturing charm of Morocco. Marrakech is a city of soul and color. Snake charmers fill plazas and dance with the mesmerized serpent. Music pours out of cafes and alleyways. The paths in the Medina twist and wind in an ancient maze meant to deter raiders, forcing them to lose their way in the swirling streets. Today those very streets add to the wonder of the historic city and the character of the people. Your private transfer meets you at the airport and soon you are venturing through the streets for an afternoon stroll. Minarets and palace towers make a lavish skyline and against the backdrop of the rambling Atlas Mountains. Djemma El Fna is the main square and entrance to the Old City. Stalls decorate the open space and fortune-tellers encourage your future. The family has stepped into a unique world of enchanted streets. It’s a combination of modern luxuries and fantastical stories. The kids are already awed by the vision of life before them. Rooftop cafes provide views to the mountains and overlook the square. The aroma of mint tea and honey swirls through the air. Donkey-drawn carts move through the alleyways. In the Old City private mansions hide behind the high walls. The interior courtyards offer a respite from the enthusiastic streets. The gardens provided a touch of countryside to the cityscape. The marvels of Morocco have begun to reveal themselves and you have only just arrived.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – In the Spirit of Things
dayInfo.description: Wake up to the sounds of the courtyard fountain trickling in the morning light. The water adds a pleasurable mist to the square. Flowers blossom and bring color to the graceful outdoor escape that takes you from the center of the city to the countryside. Staying in a refurbished Riad combines the elegance of lavish royals with the fun of experiencing history first hand. The kids are overwhelmed with excitement at the prospect of staying in a room that may have been inhabited by a royal court. The water fixture focal point helps cool the summer heat and also adds reflective beauty of the textile artistry. Breakfast arrives in the courtyard. The aroma of fig and pomegranates are sweet and colorful. The kids taste everything with vigor; enjoying the new flavors. You delight in their excitement and the fact that they are trying something new. Your guide meets you at the hotel and escorts you through the treasured streets of the classic city on a private tour. The Koutoubia Mosque has a minaret that rises over 229 feet over the cityscape. Spires are surrounded by delicate orbs. It can be seen from all directions of the city like a graceful beacon. The mosque was constructed in the 12th century and its sandstone material makes the façade shine pink in the sunlight. The windows are shaped like horseshoes and bordered by a rectangle of woven designs. The call to prayer spreads from the minaret five times a day. The voice chants, but it sounds like a poetic song that glides through the streets. Moorish decoration is prevalent in both the shapes on the walls and the symmetrical nature of the mosque’s entire design. Every moment with the family in the storybook history of Marrakech creates a unique memory enjoyed by everyone.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – Stories Come Alive
dayInfo.description: With the day at your leisure you can discover the edges of the city that has embraced your family from the moment it arrived. Venture to Almoravid Koubba, the oldest monument in the city, or luxuriate in the mountain village charm of Imlil, a quiet town with an impressive fortress overlooking the hillside. Outside of the cityscape is the Tizi-n’Test Pass. The mountains provide a scenic backdrop to the rich landscape of the countryside. The panorama is filled with rolling peaks and hillsides all the way to the horizon. The pass reaches a height of 6,867 feet above sea level. The valley floor is fertile, filled with the bountiful waters of the Nfiss River. Whether enjoying the calm of a rooftop café or exploring the switchback ridges of the pass, you will be immersed in the storybook landscape by day, and the celebrated mythology by night. For dinner you will adventure through the tales of desert in an expressive show of 1001 Nights. Sit within traditional tents in a historic compound. The aromas of freshly baked breads and stewing meats waft around you. The kids enjoy the cultural flavor of sitting on cushioned pillows. A palm-grove provides ample ambiance. When the music begins, so does the show. You are swept up in the tales of troops and musicians, acrobats and unforgettable storytellers. Dancers accompany caravans. Horse riders perform acrobats as they circle around the arena on Arab steeds. A flying carpet passes overhead. You aren’t just listening to the stories but are situated among them.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – Called to the Essaouira Seaside
dayInfo.description: The songs of the previous night echo in your head with spellbinding rhythm; you wonder if it was all a dream. When the kids come to breakfast they wear effervescent smiles and hum the same songs that played in your head as you awoke. The stories were real and the magic carpet ride was enchanting. The entire breakfast is filled with the kids’ retelling of their favorite stories and performances from last night, from the regal horses to the flipping acrobats. After your meal your private transfer meets you at the hotel to take you to Essaouira for the day. The fisherman’s town sits on the Atlantic coast and embodies charm. The atmosphere is remarkably different than Marrakech. The streets are calm and tranquil. The water brushes against the rocky coastline. The city walls rise against the alcove. When you wander through the city walls you can see the unique preservation of the 18th century European military architecture. Brass cannons are situated along the ramparts and look out to sea. The buildings are an Andalusian white and blue. Ocean spray fills the air with rejuvenating mist. When you look out over the water you can see sporadic fishing boats sailing across the horizon. The colorful trim of the sails stands out against the water and the sky. Seagulls glide over the walls and you find the definitive Moroccan city inside the ramparts. The narrow alleyways are filled with the scents of spices and wood. Palm trees cast shadows over the squares. The relaxed pace invites you in and the old walls inspire the kids. The city is a haven for artists. The sun casts its natural light over the narrow streets and reflects off of the water. In the evening you return to Marrakech and the familiar comforts of your hotel.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – Adventuring the Mountains
dayInfo.description: The mountains near the city’s edges are the first to step out of the night’s shadows. Djemaa el-Fna comes to life with music and the jovial cries of merchants. After breakfast your private guide meets you at the hotel and takes you along the desert road to Kik Plateau. The foothills rise higher and the city fades into the distance. The mountain peaks come closer but remain in the clear blue sky. Their snowy peaks look like clouds. The golden landscape turns verdant, plush with prairies and trees. The aroma of the countryside is an earthen cool. The slopes are covered with woods and the snowmelt provides cold water down the lower regions of the mountain, feeding into the tall grasses and blossoming flowers. Lake Lalla Takarkoust is pristine. Blue water reflects the rising mountainside. The breeze is cold from the higher atmosphere. The family members will marvel at the natural beauty that surrounds them, a departure from the desert air of the morning in Marrakech. Sporadic villages rise along the foothills en route. The Ourika River caters to the lushness of the valley. The meandering foothills have created a network of waterfalls throughout the region, including the tiered cascade of Ourika Falls. Atop Kik Plateau you experience more than just the countryside: you discover the natural splendor of Morocco, separate from the cities but indelibly etched into the culture. When you reach to top you stand at a point surrounded by mountaintops 13,123 feet above sea level.

dayInfo.title: Ouarzazate – On the Border
dayInfo.description: Venture outside of the reaches of Marrakech and to the gates of the desert. After breakfast, your guide will meet you at the hotel and whisk the family to the edges of civilization where golden sands carpet the landscape. Ouarzazate is a dramatic fortress than encapsulates the image of a desert kingdom. The Kasbah was erected in the 1920s by French colonial authority. The region is iconic: it can found in films, creating the backdrop of ancient civilizations, modern Somalia, and even Tibet. The desert foothills are speckled with Berber villages. The red and golden gorge is home to the Oasis du Fint. The incredible display of enduring nature shines as palm trees rise out of the Mars-like landscape. The desert air blends with the freshness of the trees. Ouarzazate’s old town looks like a city made from the golden sand. If you stepped a few yards away from the buildings, they would blend back in with the desert. The maze of stairwells and streets in the fortress takes you a prayer room on the top floor of the fortress. Keyhole archways open the main gallery. The village provides marvelous wares hidden inside the labyrinth of historic walls. Look over the cliffs at the fortress’s back. The craggy terrain is gives way to lush trees in the springtime. The city is an enigmatic symbol of the past, which captivates the kids and adds to the endless stories already circling in their heads.

dayInfo.title: Marrakech – Storybook Ending
dayInfo.description: The stories of Morocco continue to inspire the family. The sun peeks over the mountaintops and spreads across the cityscape. The images of Marrakech are inspiring, from the colorful markets to the ineffable mosques. The family has wandered through history and immersed itself in the culture. They did not just see the artistry and people, but experienced it. Your private transfer meets you at the airport and soon you board your flight home. The magnificence of Morocco has created legends and will provide indescribable memories to come.

placesVisited: Rabat, Tangier, Fez, Merzouga, Ouarzazate, Marrakech, Essaouira, Casablanca, Chefchaouen
generalInfo: Minarets and fortress towers create an unforgettable skyline. Mountaintops separate lush valleys from desolate desert sands. The sweet ocean scent of the Atlantic blows through labyrinthine streets. Your handcrafted tour of Morocco introduces you to mouthwatering food and legendary palaces, blossoming marketplaces and enchanting snake charmers. Morocco is an endless adventure filled with remarkable color and unforgettable mystique. Relax in charming renovated mansions and wander along the Road of 1,000 Kasbahs to experience the splendor spread across desert and mountains, coastline and gorges.

dayInfo.title: Imperial Arrivals
dayInfo.description: Welcome to Morocco, a country whose culture is ingrained in the landscape and emanates from the cuisine. Arrive in Casablanca where your private guide and transfer are waiting. The city sits at the country’s western edge, against the quiet lull of the Atlantic Ocean. Palm trees border wide boulevards. The trees sway in the delicate sea breeze. The sweet scent of coconut mixes with the salty sea air. Historic neighborhoods edge contemporary Art Deco buildings erected during French colonialism. A cosmopolitan ambiance can be felt through the cityscape, from award-winning restaurants to contemporary art galleries displaying aesthetics that shy away from the more classic Moroccan images. Hassan II Mosque looks out over the cobalt water. The ocean laps at the small wall that pushes against the ocean. The minaret stands 689 feet tall, the largest minaret in the world. The sunlight glints off of the water and inside of the mosque you can see the ocean wading beneath the glass floor of the main hall. The walls contain an opulent shimmer, constructed with decadent hand crafted marble. Over 100,000 worshipers can pray inside the mosque, with 25,000 inside the main hall. Walk through the multi-colored arches and notice the engraved floral designs. The elegance of the mosque reveals Morocco’s contemporary connection to its boisterous and flamboyant heritage.

dayInfo.title: Morocco’s Edge
dayInfo.description: Breakfast is filled with aromas and flavors that feel oddly familiar and uniquely foreign. Honey and melted butter combine to create a sweet and creamy syrup poured over Beghrir , a savory pancake made from semolina. After breakfast, you make your way northbound towards the Strait of Gibraltar and to the famous city of Tangier. The city sits across from Spain and has served as the entryway to the Mediterranean. Tangier has always been a bridge between the European and African continents, attracting people from around the world with enthusiasm and mystique. The city is divided between the medina, an antique area surrounded by historic walls, and the modern city. Inside the medina, you find narrow alleyways that wind around the cityscape, lined with stuccoed walls and cobbled streets. The Grand Socco is the main square fringed with palm trees. A fountain sits at the center and provides a pleasurable, cooling mist to the air. At the edge of the plaza is a keyhole gate known as Bab Fass. The terrace offers a view of the square from up high, where the romantic image of Morocco’s past comes to vibrant life.

dayInfo.title: Bathed in Blue
dayInfo.description: Every morning is an introduction into the stunning and detailed cuisine of Morocco. Today, breakfast is filled with the crisp aroma of fresh, herbaceous tea zested with orange citrus. You leave Tangier behind and make your way through vast plains. The air is perfumed with fresh grass and in the distance you can see the rising foothills of the Rif Mountains. The range has an elevation of 8,054 feet and casts imposing shadows over the valley below. You come to the 15th-century city of Chefchaouen. You find the buildings situated beneath the mountain peaks and awash in vibrant blue. The old streets wind and wander along the mountainside lined with stucco homes shining sky blue with cobalt doors. Some buildings were constructed in the Andalusian style, with red-tiled roofs. 11 towers rise above the old walls and once provided protection to the medieval city. Walk through the shaded lanes and it looks like you are exploring a city underwater with the various shades of blue encircling the streets; it is a unique atmosphere. At the heart of the old city is a plaza paved in cobblestones. Cafes and restaurants provide ambiance and a collection of delicate and rich aromas: fresh pressed dark roast coffee mingles with freshly brewed mint tea. The red walls of the Kasbah encroach on the old square and contrast with the smooth colors of the city.

dayInfo.title: Distant Blue
dayInfo.description: The colors of Chefchaouen fade into the silhouette of the mountain peaks as you make your way to the medieval city of Fez. En route to the imperial city, you stop at the Meknes, the 17th century capital of Morocco known for its 24-mile long walls that protected the city from invaders. Meknes has a slow and relaxed pace with a collection of narrow alleys that wind around the old city. The architecture provides reminders of the nobility that once called the city home. The Middle Atlas Mountains rise in the distance swooping downward into the fertile plains that surround the city. Dashes of olives, grapes, and lemons provide aromatics to the city streets. Dar Jamaï Museum is situated in the 19th century palace. The garden maintains its lavish Arab style with vibrant fruit trees and shady cypress trees. The palace windows are painted and framed by detailed tile arrangements and decorated wooden panels. The décor alone is a surviving symbol of nobility’s wealth and dedication to art and culture. Today the palace maintains one of the country’s great museums, filled with talented craftsmen and artists. The main hall is a postcard-like in its central elegant fountain surrounded by graceful arches amidst traditional Islamic geometric tiles.

dayInfo.title: Spirited Center
dayInfo.description: Fez is often considered the spiritual and cultural center of Morocco. The medieval city reached its peak between the 13th and 14th centuries. The city is inherently tied to its past, with tradesmen utilizing the same methods employed hundreds of years ago, utilizing tradition over modernization. Venture through the main gate known as Bab Bou Jeloud. The powerful triple arched entrance is decorated with glistening blue tiles. The central arch is flanked by two narrow keystone openings. The city bustles from the moment you enter, filled with a wealth of energy. The marketplace is alive with locals and visitors, spreading down a long stretch of lane. Spices are arranged in conical peaks that display their color as much as their aroma. It looks like rainbows have been separated and sold by their individual striped hues. Silks are draped over stores and flow with effortlessness and grace against the fast moving market. The aroma of leather sweeps through the meandering alleys and emanating from the famous tanneries, almost hidden behind the leather shops. Behind the vendors, you can see people stepping into the tannery pits to dye, clean, and dry leather before it is shaped into various goods.

dayInfo.title: The Desert Luster
dayInfo.description: Fez dwindles into the distance as your private transfer ferries you away from the medieval city and through a sensual cedar forest. The spiced aroma from the trees fills the air as you climb through the foothills of the Middle Atlas Mountains. Continue through a series of valleys known as the Ziz Gorges where the Ziz River cuts through the Atlas Mountains. Hills climb up to 1,050 feet with a canyon walls that reach a width of 656 feet. The lush greenery looks like an oasis against the backdrop of cliffs layered with red and black rock. When you reach the town of Erfoud a 4x4 collects you and takes you into the vast Sahara Dessert for a panorama of unparalleled scenery. The wonders of the desert begin at the edges of the golden sand and spread into the vast unknown. The 4x4 reaches Erg Chebbi, possibly the largest collection of sand dunes in the Sahara with dunes that tower like mountains almost 525 feet into above the level field. The late afternoon provides a breeze over the sweeping sands. The beauty of the landscape is in its seclusion and pristine nature. The sunset gives way to endless starlight flickering above the dunes.

dayInfo.title: More than Desert Grounds
dayInfo.description: The towering and imposing dunes fade behind the horizon and give way to the oases around Dades and Todra Gorges. The Dades River swirls through the valleys and gives life to nut trees and palms that fill the area with greenery and buttery fragrance. The canyon walls of Todra Gorge rise 900 feet high and stretch for upwards of 300 feet long. You can’t help but marvel at the stunning landscape as you make your way into the Valley of 1,000 Kasbahs, situated between the High Atlas Mountains and the Jbel Sarhro Mountains. In Skoura, you find remnants of what was once a vibrant desert trading post. Graceful palm groves create a vast contrast to the desolate desert sands. The canopy shades almost 15 miles of gardens watered by a water system of locks, levees, and canals with centuries of experience. Birds flutter and twitter around the oasis. The golden towers of a historic fortress rise out of the canopy. Kasbah Amridil was constructed in the 17th century and appears on the 50-dirham note. The doors contain hand carved locks and the village life displays olive presses and bread ovens that continue to function.

dayInfo.title: Architecture of the Desert
dayInfo.description: The desert landscape has changed from the meandering dunes to a rocky arid expanse that brushes against the rusty-red cliffs. Outside of Ouarzazate you make your way to Telouet, home to the “Lord of the Atlas,” A palace that has watched over the desert landscape since the 19th century. The town rests at an elevation of 5,900 feet and was the former seat of power to the El Glaoui family. The red sand Kasbah walls look ruinous from the outside. However, once inside the Glaoui Palace you find a museum filled with opulence dating back to the family’s pinnacle of prominence. Wooden doors are decorated with hand carved geometric shapes. The walls are decorated with elegant zerij mosaics, traditional Islamic artwork. The windows are framed with latticed-style wrought iron work. The panorama fills with green fields of Berber villages. Trees almost block out the rocky outcrops and lead to mountains rolling along the horizon. The interior courtyard is paved with polished marble and lined with thin, graceful columns. The remains of the sensational palace remind you to never judge a book by its cover, or a palace by its exterior.

dayInfo.title: Inside the Earthen Walls
dayInfo.description: Venture outside of the town of Ouarzazate and find the UNESCO World Heritage site of Aït Ben Haddou. The city is famous for providing the backdrop in Hollywood movies such as Gladiator and The Mummy . The village inside the walls shifts from red to gold in the shifting sunlight. From a distance the village looks like a hill, blending into the surroundings. Corner towers reinforce the defensive walls. Houses crowd together in a stunning example of a southern Moroccan town. The earliest constructions date back to the 17th century. The scent of arid earth winds through the streets. A loft fortress overlooks the mountainside and the expansive desert. You continue through the Tizi n’Tichka mountain pass and on to Marrakech.

dayInfo.title: Cultural Bounty
dayInfo.description: Marrakech is the pulse of historic Morocco. Djemaa el Fna Square fills with remnants of the mystical and inspiring. Snake charmers play their instruments to enchant both the focused cobra and passersby. Fortunetellers read people’s palms and spin tales about the future. The scent of exotic spices blends with the aroma of orange zest and mint tea. The alleys of the medina wind away from the main square and take you on a tour of the city that feels like you are searching for buried treasure. Your guide shows you Koutoubia Mosque, a 12th-century edifice that can be seen from almost every angle of the city. An age-old ordinance states that no building can be built higher than a palm tree, but the mosque was exempted. The minaret is one of the three oldest remaining Almohad minarets in the world and stands almost 230 feet tall. A book market once blossomed near the base of the minaret and filled the nearby square. Ceramic tiles create a dazzling band at the top over inspiring decorative motifs. A topper of copper orbs captures the sunlight and shines above the old city. Your exploration of Marrakech has just begun and you already have seen historic wonder and marvelous mystique.

dayInfo.title: Moment in the Mountains
dayInfo.description: The morning fills with the now familiar aromas of mint tea and sweet honey. Your plush, antique surroundings open up to the remarkable history of the medina and the culture encapsulated within it. You make your way into the High Atlas Mountains during the day for a breath of fresh, mountain air and a visit to Kasbah du Toubkal. The roads wind around the foothills with hairpin turns to bring you into the mountain range that rises to an elevation of 13,671. The fortress stands above the wild tree line and blossoming lupines. Sporadic purple and pink flower petals poke out of the lush greenery. The hillside continues to rise over the old fortress into the mountaintops. You can reach the village of Imlil by a muleteer path that winds along the rolling mountainscape. The sweet aroma of budding flowers mixes with the verdant trees. The village rises along the sloping landscape. In the drier months the earthen homes blend into the arid mountains. The mountains are more than just a view but a reward, opening up like a time capsule. From the Kasbah rooftop you can sip a soothing cup of tea and watch the colors of the mountains change with the shifting sunlight.

dayInfo.title: The Sea and Walls
dayInfo.description: West of Marrakech is the charming town of Essaouira. The walls wrap around the old Phoenician trading post and press against the Atlantic Ocean. The sweet aroma of the sea rises in the breeze. The warm sun is cooled by the ocean spray that lingers around the twisting historic streets. The Atlantic shines cobalt blue. The walls were built by the Portuguese and protected the outpost for centuries. The streets have a relaxed ambiance that creates a carefree atmosphere. Seagulls soar over the walls and narrow alleys turn the town’s center into a maze. Local women wear white veils and palm trees cast shadows and shade over the red walls. Modern gourmet coffee shops stand next to historic old restaurants. You listen to the waves brush against the shore and can stand on the dramatic ramparts for a view of the historic, labyrinthine streets. A sea bastion on the cliffs gives you access to the city walls. 18th and 19th century brass cannons continue to look outward, ever-watchful sentinels. The horizon along the ocean is clear and calm. Whitewashed houses are decorated with heavy wooden doors. People roam through the streets without a care and don’t notice you enjoying your unique panorama.

dayInfo.title: Old Styles of New Life
dayInfo.description: The sunlight spreads over the valley and onto the sapphire water outlining the walled city. The day in Essaouira is to be experienced at your own pace and filled with joy. Take a horseback ride along the sandy beach and feel the sea breeze comb through your hair. Venture outside of the city with the fishing boats and catch the famous Alizee winds in the sail on your own private sailing tour. In the nearby valley, halfway to Marrakech, you arrive at the legendary local winery of Val d’Argan. The vineyard was open by a French ex-pat in the 1990s and now produces some of the most celebrated wines in North Africa. The lush vines spread across the valley floor. Camels turn the soil, helping the farming. The restaurant has open screens that look out onto the plush landscape. You can tour the 100 acres of fields under cultivation and see the storage barrels of wine before enjoying a private tasting. The wines are often featured on wine lists between Marrakech and Essaouira. Sip on a chilled glass of rose beneath the warm sun. The aroma of lime flower and mature fruit linger in the glass. A nearby goat farm produces some of the region’s most renowned cheese, bringing wine and cheese together and sparking images of European flair, but in an entirely distinct environment.

dayInfo.title: Return of the Cosmopolitan
dayInfo.description: History and heritage fade into the seaside city as you journey back to Casablanca. The sophisticated culture of the city returns in swaying palms and Art Deco architecture conjuring up images of French colonialism. Upon your return you notice the contrast between the city’s contemporary heritage and the surrounding country’s classic culture. The Villa des Arts is a museum housed in a 1930s pristine white Art Deco building. The stairs are decorated with ornate black and white marble with a wrought-iron railing. The gallery exhibits sculptures and paintings from contemporary Moroccan artists. At the nearby Parc de la Ligue Arabe, local kids play soccer on the large field. Bushes blossom against the colonnade of fragrant trees. People in the financial center of Morocco work and play hard, taking time out of their fast-paced day to enjoy the sunshine, shade, and a honeyed cup of mint tea.

dayInfo.title: Past and Present Morocco
dayInfo.description: A soothing voice sings out in the morning. The Call To Prayer echoes along the neighborhoods, emanating from Hassan II Mosque. The quiet lapping of the Atlantic Ocean against the city’s shores fades beneath the morning prayer. The savory flavors of your final breakfast in Morocco are filled with spices you have grown to relish and expect. Soon your private transfer will meet you at the hotel to escort you to the airport. Your time in Morocco has taken you from seaside to desert sands, through mountain passes and valley floors. You have experienced Moroccan splendor it all its beauty, from cosmopolitan predilections to unadulterated heritage. To see more Morocco itineraries, visit the luxury Morocco tours page.

tourName: Colorful Exploration of Morocco: Ancient Cities and Expansive Deserts
placesVisited: Rabat, Chefchaouen, Fez, Merzouga, Skoura, Essaouira, Marrakech
generalInfo: No trip to Morocco is complete without enjoying the unique blend of the past and present that appears here in abundance and this 13-day tour of the country’s major sites is designed to provide plenty of both. As you wander the medinas, ksars, and kasbahs of this colorful corner of North Africa, a blend of leisure time and exclusive tours will ensure your full enjoyment of every destination you visit.

dayInfo.title: Rabat – Arriving to the Capital of Colorful Morocco
dayInfo.description: Tucked at the mouth of the Bou Regreg river, Rabat presents visitors with a head-spinning array of sights, sounds, and smells, each demonstrating a slightly different version of Morocco's multifaceted charm. As the capital of this colorful country perched on the Northwest edge of Africa, Rabat is an excellent ambassador of all things Moroccan, and you will be able to step into this vibrant setting after your flight arrives. A private transfer whisks you effortlessly into the heart of the old town and your luxury hotel.

dayInfo.title: Chefchaouen – Taking a Turn for the Rural
dayInfo.description: At the juncture of sand and sea, past and present, Rabat enjoys a privileged position. From the contours of the cityscape's minarets to the rustic old town clustered on the waterfront, or the daily prayer calls that echo off the stone facades as they have for centuries, it is hard not to fall in love with this exotic city. In the morning, you will be able to plunge into this vibrant environment on a private tour before departing the capital for your accommodations in Chefchaouen, where you will have the remainder of the day at leisure.

dayInfo.title: Fez – Ambling Through the Ages on a Tour of the Medina
dayInfo.description: Known as the blue city, a stroll through Chefchaouen as dawn breaks will reveal how the community got its name through the numerous brightly colored blue buildings and neighborhoods. After you enjoy a delicious breakfast in your luxurious hotel, you will be able to enjoy a private tour of this blue paradise by a private guide well versed with local history. As you soak up the ambient beauty of the Kasbah, medina, and various temples and mosques, this quiet corner of the country will come alive. In the afternoon, you will depart Chefchaouen and make your way south to the bustling Fez.

dayInfo.title: Fez – Visiting the Famous Tanneries
dayInfo.description: The centrally-located Fez is an outstanding gateway to adventure throughout the region. As you awake to your first full day in the city, you will be able to soak up a cosmopolitan city with an unrivaled atmosphere of modern high rises and commercial districts as well as neighborhoods that seem like time forgot them. Into this rich environment, you will step today on a private walking tour of the medina, or historic old town, as well as the famous tanneries where locals produce the city's fine leather and a host of other attractions.

dayInfo.title: Erg Chebbi Merzouga – Chasing Dunes in North Africa
dayInfo.description: No trip to Morocco is complete without paying a visit to the impressive Sahara desert, which adds a touch of legend to the local history of this vibrant country. After waking up leisurely, you will be able to enjoy a delicious breakfast at your luxurious hotel before making your way south to the Erg Chebbi Merzouga sand dunes and your boutique hotel. Upon arrival to your lush accommodations, you can end the day with the four-legged companions famous in the region. Still, if you prefer wheels over camels, all-terrain vehicles can carry you to the dunes for a sunset vista.

dayInfo.title: Erg Chebbi Merzouga – Discovering Life in the Desert
dayInfo.description: You will be able to enjoy a full day in this desert paradise, and as the sun's warming rays first touch the summits of the neighboring dunes bathing it in the morning light, you can either rise with the sun or hit the snooze button for those remaining hours of precious slumber. After a fortifying breakfast, you will embark on a guided tour of the neighboring villages and lakes where you can witness Morocco's unique wildlife as well as the charming hospitality and traditional markets of these rustic communities.

dayInfo.title: Skoura – An Exploration of the Todra Gorge
dayInfo.description: Even though you are departing the dunes, your luxurious explorations of the Moroccan desert is not over, and after you enjoy a final authentic breakfast from your luxury hotel, today you will make your way to the Skoura but not before enjoying a memorable trip to the Todra gorges with a private guide. As you amble the massive limestone cliffs of the gorges, high up in the Atlas mountains, your knowledgeable guide will happily introduce you to the local flora and fauna and the geologic origins of this stunning landscape. In the afternoon, you will make your way to Skoura and your luxury hotel.

dayInfo.title: Atlas Mountains – Visiting a Land that Time Forgot
dayInfo.description: Today the theme is timelessness, as you awake to the soft comfort of your luxurious hotel in Skoura.
